column1: Expected attributes missing from objects
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Occasionally exceptions occur which seem to indicate that an object which normal has an attribute no longer has an attribute. One theory is that there is some sort of stack corruption or data race occurring. The issue seems to occur more frequently when the validator is under load, however there is currently no known way to consistently reproduce the same error.

column1: Failure to reconnect to other validators (Disconnect after lag)
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Increased network activity can cause the dispatcher to backup and result in a validator disconnecting from its peers and rejecting all further communication. It is possible that the validator can get into a state where it is not able to complete authorization quickly enough due to high network message load. Symptoms include the dispatcher queue size spiking (normally ~11, > 100):

Jan  8 05:05:33 ec2-54-91-158-191.compute-1.amazonaws.com [psimlr1-node8]    DEBUG   OutboundConnectionThread-31                     dispatch Dispatch incoming queue size: 123

 

Followed by the permission verifier repeatedly closing connections:

Jan  8 05:33:06 ec2-54-91-158-191.compute-1.amazonaws.com [psimlr1-node8]    DEBUG                     Thread-11          permission_verifier No public key found, 0762d3710d7a3b06ff
d4e7104dada7499ee4f14b42f506311a4c15d762cebf400583a204f41b5e5e15bf3c135d09efe224ced143d8d7da1f7046f2abbcb2ba7f is not permitted. Close connection.
Jan  8 05:33:06 ec2-54-91-158-191.com
column135:
13/Mar/18 4:33 AM;adamludvik;This is also known to happen after a period of unscheduling many batches, which can be identified with the following log message:

Mar 12 04:54:07 ec2-54-227-225-89.compute-1.amazonaws.com [psimlr1-node2]    DEBUG              _PublisherThread           scheduler_parallel Removed 499 incomplete batches from the schedule;;;

column1: Go TPs return INTERNAL ERROR when internal work queue fills up
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When a Go TP's internal work queue fills up, it begins returning INTERNAL ERROR in response to validator TpProcessRequests. The validators reaction to this is to just resend the transaction, which does not help. The validator needs to be able to handle transaction process backpressure correctly and the Go SDK needs to be updated to work with the new backpressure system.

Jan 16 16:24:01 psimlr1-node0 intkey-tp-go[15036]: 2018/01/16 22:24:01.308081 processor.go:241: [WARN] Work queue is full, denying request d54f553ff35e4b8396d1300965a5e7bd

column1: Validator segfaults when under load
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Not much is known about this bug other than it happens sporadically when the validator is under load. Using systemd to restart the validator on failure seems to be a good bandage for this, but the issue needs to be diagnosed and resolved. The changes to test-poet-liveness in this branch cause the test to consistently reproduce this behavior, but how to generate and inspect the coredumps continues to be an open question

column1: Explicitly cancel candidate blocks on chain update
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently, when the chain is updated and a candidate block is in progress, it is set to {{None}} - i.e. discarded. Its schedule is cancelled when the garbage collector reclaims the object's memory. This can happen at unpredictable times, which results blocks being published which should have been abandoned.

This should be converted to an explicit cancel of the candidate block.

column1: Block Info state values not available in Transactions
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When the block-info batch injector is enabled, the batch info is not always available in every transaction. 

Steps to reproduce are forthcoming.
column135:
01/Feb/18 3:57 AM;jaredcorduan;We are trying to read the block info from inside a transaction processor, not from the rest api. The rest api always looks good, there is always block info there. The trouble is attempting to write transaction processors which depend on block info.

I wrote a transaction processor that only does the following: 1) attempt to read block info config, 2) get the latest block number, 3) attempt to read the block info for the latest block, and 4) log what happens.

If you send off <10 of these transactions to the rest api, all is lovely. but once you start sending ~15 transactions in rapid fire (not batched together), you'll see the following behavior for one of the transactions: 

The first time the transaction processor attempts to use `apply`, block info config is there and has a latest block, but there is no block info data for that latest block at the associated address. (In fact, there is no block info for any block, even block zero.) The second time the transaction processor attempts to process the transaction (ie when it is doing the `apply` for consensus), the block info is there.

Every single time block_info is missing for `latest_block`, it's in the situation where the transaction processor sees the latest block as n, but the transaction actually ends up going into block n+1.;;;
column136: 01/Feb/18 6:21 AM;jaredcorduan;I cannot reproduce this issue when using PoET simulator.;;;
column137:
01/Feb/18 7:32 AM;pschwarz;This looks like it's an issue under dev mode, where the consensus module is trying to publish blocks as fast as possible.  So it will, minimally, include only the injected batch (i.e. block info) and at least one batch submitted to the validator.  Once consensus is committed, all other batches will be unscheduled, the block will be commit, and the unscheduled batches will be put into the next candidate block's schedule. 

This is also true for PoET, but the publish times are longer, so there's a higher likelihood that batches will be included in the next block.;;;
column138: 09/Feb/18 3:15 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;[~pschwarz] do you have the resolution for this - maybe a PR #? ;;;

column1: Add in-process transactions metric
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Add a metric to the executor to track the number of transactions that have been sent to a transaction processor and are awaiting a transaction response. This should be incremented whenever a new transaction process request is submitted and decremented whenever a response is received.

column1: Log at error level when an INTERNAL_ERROR is returned from a transaction processor
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: The executor should log whenever a transaction processor sends a TpProcessResponse with status INTERNAL_ERROR. This should be logged at the ERROR level. Additional information about the transaction should also be logged for diagnosis.

column1: Update `sawtooth identity policy create` to replace space between "PERMIT_KEY <key>"
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently requiring this space caused issue when trying to $(cat file) where the file contained "PERMIT_KEY <key1>" "PERMIT_KEY <key2>" etc.. 

The space between the rule and the key should be replaced by comma or some other delimiating character.

column1: Update Examples with Componentized Address Mapping & State Encoding
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Refactor the XO transaction family (Python, Javascript, Go) such that state encoding and address mapping are distinct from the game logic. The goal of this effort is to restructure the transaction family for the purposes of better application developer guide flow.

column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Transaction processors should provide the validator with a "level of parallelism" hint which the validator then uses to determine how many transactions it can have in-flight to a given transaction processor.

column1: Enhance Workload Intkey Generation Tool
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Develop a new intkey-workload CLI tool which uses the perf/sawtooth_workload library and has the following features:

a) Usable in LR environments
b) A seed option to specify the random seed, with the goal of creating predictable workloads
c) A URL option allowing multiple REST API URLs to be specified for batch submission
d) A rate option to control the batches submitted per second
e) Support for Basic Auth
f) An option to specify the number of variable names to be used
g) An option to occasionally send a wildcard for input/output fields
h) An option to occasionally set an otherwise-unnecessary dependency on a previous transaction

Develop enhancements to the perf/sawtooth_workload library as necessary to achieve the above features.

Once the "intkey-workload" command is complete, the older "intkey workload" will be deprecated.

column1: Fix smallbank workload to not use "wait" query parameter.
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: The intkey workload uses repeated /batch_statuses requests instead of using the "wait" query parameter. Using "wait" requires holding open sockets which consumes an inordinate amount of OS resources on the client side, and probably the rest-api too.

column1: Uncommitted Injected Batches Are Put in Pending Queue
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: When a block is uncommitted and has an injected batch, the injected batch will be put into the pending queue.  This is due to the injected batch being not being included in any other batches published from other nodes in the network.  The chain controller is unaware about the batches injected nature when it passes this info back to the block publisher.

column1: Split off predecessor tree's tree
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently the parallel scheduler's predecessor tree is implemented in such a way that its tree logic is mixed in with its predecessor logic.

Split off the tree data structure into a separate class with the following interface:
 * walk(address)
 * prune(address)
 * update(address, update_function)

column1: Parallel scheduler state root hash calculation is non-deterministic
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Computation of a blocks state root hash appears to be non-deterministic when using the parallel scheduler and the smallbank transaction processor. The calculated state root hash can be influenced by changing the PYTHONHASHSEED environment variable at startup. The following  message is a symptom of this problem,

state:52fa4b7a2009e28bf81c04fd223bf32d8b183e0db49cd6c5b1441e9fa45b8a16, previous_block_id:f365d0e29c9c53cc3c372d0b2baec8737704f63e6fcfaa05910f4bd476c37a970bace3de7dca6cd4c7f7abc6b1498574aa9145d6f05da8cc90b85f0a2706ed40) failed state root hash validation. Expected 52fa4b7a2009e28bf81c04fd223bf32d8b183e0db49cd6c5b1441e9fa45b8a16 but got 21a97659ff375aeb552fdc6178b34f46146df40fd31d4a0b79e827fe7043a27c

column1: Convert predecessor tree's data structure to prefix tree
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Currently the predecessor tree allocates a separate node for each token in the addresses it receives, and most of these nodes are not used. Make the tree compact by changing the nodes to represent the common prefix of their children.

column1: Make Thread pool configuration for Chain Controller
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
In the documentation on ChainController there is a note saying:


"Currently, the thread pool is set to 1, so only one Block is validated at a time."

 

On checking the code, I found out that the thread pool configuration for the BlockValidator hardcoded to 1. Can this be made configurable?

column1: Checking block_info state in Intkey creates bug in validator
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Description:* When the block_info data is get from another transaction family, the information can miss (despite block_info being injected first) and this leads to undesired behavior for the validator.

*Reproducibility:* The bug is reproducible with the following modifications to the Intkey transaction family. Have any Intkey transaction get the timestamp from the block_info. Whe the block_info information is missing then Intkey raise an InternalError exception. This InternalError exception is causing the validator to retry to execute the transaction at the next block – which is fine -- but the block_info is missing for every attempt of the validator. This leads to validator spinning forever trying to execute the same transaction again and again with the same InternalError exception. The Intkey Smoke test has been modified to send 100 Intkey transactions with a SLEEP_BETWEEN_TXN = 0.03 in between. The value of 0.03 appears to be a threshold triggering the bug on our machine.

The following branch allows to reproduce the bug: [https://github.com/benoitrazet/sawtooth-core/tree/block_info_missing_bug]

start the validator and the other containers in one terminal:

./bin/run_docker_test test_intkey_smoke_python

in another terminal enter the test container and then run the test

docker exec -it latest_test-intkey-smoke-python_1 bash

nose2-3 -c /project/sawtooth-core/integration/sawtooth_integration/nose2.cfg -v -s /project/sawtooth-core/integration/sawtooth_integration/tests test_intkey_smoke.TestIntkeySmoke

Looking at the logs of the first terminal should show validator trying execute forever some intkey transactions that miss the block_info.

*Remarks:* the same type of bug occurs when the transaction family checks `sawtooth settings` instead of block_info. This suggests that it is not a block_info per se but a broader validator bug.

column1: Validator freeze when too many batches are submitted
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Description:* When there are too many batches submitted concurrently through one rest api, the validator freezes.

*Reproducibility:* The bug is reproducible with the following modification to the Intkey test using the Python SDK. Submit additional Intkey transaction at high frequency in the test test_intkey_smoke.python.py and run concurrently more than 50 instances of this test.

The following branch allows to reproduce the bug: [https://github.com/benoitrazet/sawtooth-core/tree/validator_freeze]

start the validator and the other containers in one terminal:

./bin/run_docker_test test_intkey_smoke_python

in another terminal enter the test container and then run the test

docker exec -it latest_test-intkey-smoke-python_1 bash

for i in \{1..100}; do nose2-3 -c /project/sawtooth-core/integration/sawtooth_integration/nose2.cfg -v -s /project/sawtooth-core/integration/sawtooth_integration/tests test_intkey_smoke.TestIntkeySmoke & sleep 0.1 ; done

Looking at the logs of the first terminal should show eventually the validator freezing

*Remarks:*
 * we have observed that sometimes, if a 2nd restapi is connected to the validator, it is possible to submit transactions to this 2nd rest-api and the validator will process the batches. 
 * We have observed (without guaranteed reproducibility) that sometimes once the validator freezes, it may eventually unfreeze (after several minutes) and be able to process new batches submitted.
column135: 16/Feb/18 6:18 AM;pschwarz;This is a symptom of the same problem caused by unscheduled transactions that return an {{InternalError}};;;
column136: 16/Feb/18 7:23 AM;pschwarz;A commit was added that removed that problem, so now it is isolated to just high volume;;;

column1: Pending Queue Limit improperly calculated
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The pending queue limit is improperly calculated in the {{BlockPublisher._rebuild_pending_batches}} method.  This is using the list of committed batches which include batches across whole forks, not just a single block.  

Correct this to only update the rolling average based on a block's batch count

Proposed organization:

 - Summary of XO gameplay (business logic for the XO TP)
 - Starting the xo transaction processor (add xo-tp to the development environment)

column1: App Developers Guide does not use consistent prompt to represent CLI container
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: In [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/latest/app_developers_guide/docker.html,]  *root@75b380886502:/#* is used to represent input into the CLI container and *$* is used to represent input into the host computer in the _Confirming Connectivity_ section.  However, in the ___Creating and Submitting Transactions with_ intkey section, a *$* is used even though these commands should be entered from the CLI container. Recommend using consistent prompts.

column1: Convert publisher debug messages to metrics
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: The publisher has debug messages that would be better represented as metrics, for instance "Batch %s invalid, not added to block". This message tends to get dumped into the logs in big batches, making it hard to tell how often it is or should be occurring.

column1: Publisher marks batches invalid en masse
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Around the time of an unrecovered fork, one node's publisher logged this message en masse: "Batch %s invalid, not added to block."

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1073 will probably make it easier to tell if these events are related.

column1: Convert peering messages to metrics
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Some peering messages get logged over and over and over, for instance "No public key found, %s is not permitted. Close connection." and "Peers are: %s. Unpeered candidates are: %s"

It might be better to replace these message or at least supplement them with metrics. This should be done in coordination with https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1024.

column1: XO Family specification missing delete operation; clarify name fields; fix range
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Defect in version 1.0.1

The XO Transaction family specification should include the transaction action `delete`

The `name` field of the transactions and the state element should indicate that is the name of the game and that is how the record is keyed. The implication being that all game names must be unique 

The range of values for a `space` should be [1,9] inclusive.
column136:
30/Aug/18 4:16 AM;achenette;Also, the "Execution" section of the XO spec should describe the delete action:

https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/transaction_family_specifications/xo_transaction_family.html#execution;;;

column1: CXX SDK Support for adding data and events to the transaction receipt
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Sawtooth allows transaction processors adding any data and events to the transaction receipts and number of SDKs (e.g. python) have already supported these capability.

This task is to add similar capabilities to the CXX SDK.

column1: Fix executor data race
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: In the executor, the _execute_or_wait_for_processor methods have a data race when adding waiters to the _WaitersByType data structure. This functionality should be made atomic to avoid a race condition

column1: Validators forking/consensus issues
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Description:* It seems that when a network of 5 validators is deployed, the validators easily fork and do not reach consensus after even a small number of transactions.

*Reproducibility1:* see comment https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1081?focusedCommentId=41152&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-41152

*Reproducibility2:* The bug is reproducible with the following modifications to the Intkey transaction family. A new verb is introduced *append*. It differs from inc/dec because it will preserve the order of operations by not being associative-commutative.

The following branch allows to reproduce the bug: [https://github.com/benoitrazet/sawtooth-core/tree/fork-consensus-issues]

To see the bug, run:

./bin/run_docker_test test_poet_liveness2.yaml

and observe the logs that eventually shows difficulties to reach consensus with messages like the following when the validators appear to have forked:
```
intkey-workload_1 | V0 \{'nasscom': 80150160}
intkey-workload_1 | V1 \{'nasscom': 102030405060708090100110120130}
intkey-workload_1 | V2 \{'nasscom': 80150160}

intkey-workload_1 | V3 \{'nasscom': 80150}
intkey-workload_1 | V4 \{'nasscom': 80150160}

intkey-workload_1 | INFO:test_intkey_smoke:The nasscom value for each validator should be the same
intkey-workload_1 | INFO:test_intkey_smoke:There are 3 different branches.
```

*Remarks:*
 * The Intkey transaction family was also modified to raise InvalidTranaction instead of InternalError.
 * The docker-compose file is very close to test_poet_liveness. Mostly the Inkey-go transaction processor has been replaced with the Python one.
 * The same behavior is observable using the devmode consensus instead of software PoET
column135: 27/Feb/18 11:17 PM;benoit.razet;I noticed something that might be important. In the tests, it is always validator 1 and 3 that struggle to catch up or reach consensus. Whereas validators 0, 2 and 4 seem to be okay. I noticed that in the toml file configuring the validators the former are using the *serial scheduler*, whereas the latter are using the *parallel scheduler*. Therefore, there may be a bug in the serial scheduler.;;;
column136: 28/Feb/18 12:11 AM;benoit.razet;Setting up all the validators with the parallel scheduler does not trigger the bug, therefore the serial scheduler might have some issues;;;
column137: 28/Feb/18 10:15 PM;benoit.razet;Setting up all the validators with the *serial* scheduler triggers the bug (validators forking, not reaching consensus). It's not only that they fork but also that they start working extremely slowly (processing transaction very slowly, if not even frozen).;;;
column139:
01/Mar/18 4:49 AM;benoit.razet;The undesired behavior of validators is observable under low volume of transactions. The test does 1txn every 3 seconds.

When the rate of transactions is the highest tolerable by the rest-api, the validators seem to stay in sync, at least for around 5 mins.;;;
column140:
03/Mar/18 1:10 AM;benoit.razet;To see the bug with the serial scheduler, simply use the test_poet_liveness and decrease the volume of transactions from 1txn/sec to 0.2txn/sec.

I did this on smallbank_workload and deactivate the intkey_workload, and the forking/consensus appears

!Screen Shot 2018-03-02 at 11.09.26 AM.png|width=883,height=63! This clearly shows the validators using serial scheduler (val1 and val3) getting out of sync with the validators using the parallel scheduler.

Remark: I had to modify the rust program doing the smallbank-workload because it seems the program would not accept less that 1txn/sec workload.;;;
column142: 22/May/19 12:53 AM;benoit.razet;[~pschwarz] Thanks for revisiting this bug report. The problem was in the serial scheduler. If I remember correctly, the serial scheduler was not really maintained for several months. It would be interesting to check the status of the bug using Transact.;;;
column143: 11/Jun/19 4:28 AM;pschwarz;I will close this issue, with the work-around to use the parallel scheduler.;;;

column1: Unhandled attribute error in executor thread
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
This error was seen during a local state verifier run:
|[2018-02-27 18:06:52.998 ERROR executor] Unhandled exception while executing schedule: '_ManagerCollection' object has no attribute 'state_hash'|
|Traceback (most recent call last):|
|File "/project/sawtooth-core/validator/sawtooth_validator/execution/executor.py", line 170, in execute_thread|
|self._execute_schedule()|
|File "/project/sawtooth-core/validator/sawtooth_validator/execution/executor.py", line 273, in _execute_schedule|
|state_hash=txn_info.state_hash,|
|AttributeError: '_ManagerCollection' object has no attribute 'state_hash'|

In this run, `verify_state` (
[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/9a952aaeeff98031ccd3179c0faee13cef80912e/validator/sawtooth_validator/server/state_verifier.py#L52|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/9a952aaeeff98031ccd3179c0faee13cef80912e/validator/sawtooth_validator/server/state_verifier.py#L52_]) was called on a store of 300 blocks with transaction processors but no validator (and hence no peering, etc).
 
This may be related to (or even the same as) https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1019.

column1: Go Transaction Processor fail to Reconnect
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When a Golang transaction processor is connected to a validator, and the validator is restarted after a crash, the transaction processor does not reconnect.

Steps to reproduce:

1) start a validator node with smallbank-tp
2) crash the validator (e.g. with a segfault)

Expected Behavior: 

The smallbank-tp reconnects to the validator and can process transactions

Actual Behavior:

The smallbank-tp does not send a registration message

column1: Cache deserialized message content between handlers
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Individual handlers are responsible for deserializing message content, which results in inefficiency when multiple message handlers are used. Before a message is passed to a series of handlers, it should be optionally deserialized and cached and the cached value is passed to the handlers

column137:
21/Mar/18 7:50 AM;FrankC01;Peter

We can use the github repo of our code or were you thinking I hack together a TP to reproduce for you?;;;
column138: 23/Mar/18 1:58 AM;pschwarz;I would like something that I can run where I can debug the validator while its running.  A simple TP would be great.;;;
column139: 23/Mar/18 2:41 AM;FrankC01;The easiest to do would be to clone our repo, quick build and run... if that is acceptable to you I will setup a wiki page to do that and recreate, let me know;;;
column140:
23/Mar/18 7:18 PM;FrankC01;Peter

Here are the recreation steps:

Assumes local sawtooth-core repo cloned and built (at least for python)

To reproduce issue:

1. Clone hashblock-exchange branch specific to this issue

_git clone -b STL-1105 [https://github.com/hashblock/hashblock-exchange.git|https://github.com/hashblock/hashblock-exchange.git_]_

2. From hashblock-exchange root

_bin/build_all_
 _docker-compose -f docker/compose/hashblock-local.yaml up_

3. from another window

_docker exec -it hashblock-shell bash_
 _txq ask -x 5.bags\{peanuts}_
 _txq list # This will list the new 'state' address and you can verify via rest-api_

4. With the address for the first trans shown in the list command, complete the killer step. In the last part of the command keep the single quotes as shown:

_txq tell_ \
 -a <address from list> \
 _-x '$10\{usd}' @ '$2\{usd}' for 1.bag\{peanuts}_

5. The log should be showing the loop/exception;;;
column141:
15/May/18 1:35 PM;rranjan3;This was a case of update in the states where set and delete operations were done at one go. Set items were being handled before the deletion which was causing some  expected data to be deleted. This threw an error which kept the batch from being cleaned up. This further caused the scheduler to pick up the same batch again and again after the schedule interval(infinte loop). Proper state is ensured during rehashing bottom-up now.

Has been fixed in master as well as backported to 1-0-staging-01([PR-1614|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1614]) [~pschwarz].;;;

column1: Parallel scheduler doesn't handle checks for predecessors of predecessors of ... correctly
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1468] This PR includes yaml scheduler tests that show the behavior. In ParallelScheduler._get_initial_state_for_transaction, the check in predecessor_not_in_chain builds up predecessors of the transactions whose state is included for the current txn and then doesn't add any predecessors of these transactions. The correct check should probably be that not only predecessors of these transactions but any predecessor of a predecessor (and so on) should not be included.

There is a second incorrect check surrounding "replay of successors", and txn is a "successor that needs to be replayed" if it is any predecessor of a predecessor (and so on) not just a predecessor.

column1: Transaction Processor (JAVA SDK) gets stuck in run loop after disconnect
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Issue*

When validator is restarted,  transaction process (sawtooth.sdk.processor.TransactionProcessor) gets stuck in the run loop and does not exit the run loop nor it tries to reconnect to the validator.  

 

*Exception*
{code:java}
sawtooth.sdk.processor.exceptions.ValidatorConnectionError: The connection to the validator was lost
at sawtooth.sdk.messaging.FutureError.setResult(FutureError.java:53)
at sawtooth.sdk.messaging.SendReceiveThread$Receiver.handle(SendReceiveThread.java:117)
at org.zeromq.ZLoop.start(ZLoop.java:307)
at sawtooth.sdk.messaging.SendReceiveThread.run(SendReceiveThread.java:178)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
{code}
*Expected Behavior*

I was expecting transaction processor to throw an exception / so that caller can restart the processor.

column1: Validator synchronization issue after transaction processor dissconnects
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When running multiple validators, we noticed that when transaction processor is restarted on one of the nodes,  the validator on that node stops processing future blocks even after the transaction processor is up.

In some cases, it also affects other nodes and all of them go out of sync.

*Steps to reproduce*

For simulating this issue locally, I used a modified version of docker-compose file that runs 3 validators, 3 API containers, and 3 copy of default transaction processor :

[https://gist.github.com/sukrit007/393f098af0a94c21db68decf4887f8a8]

 
 * Start all containers using docker-compose up
 * 
{code:java}
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey set test 100 --url=http://rest-api3:8008
sleep 5s
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api2:8008

# Stop intkey tp for validator2
docker-compose stop intkey-tp-python2

# Submit batch on validator2
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey inc test 10 --url=http://rest-api2:8008
sleep 5s

# Check value on all the  validators
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api:8008
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api2:8008
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api3:8008

# Start transaction processor for validator2
docker-compose start intkey-tp-python2

# Submit batch on validator2
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey inc test 10 --url=http://rest-api2:8008
sleep 60s

# Check value on all the  validators
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api:8008
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api2:8008
docker exec -it sawtooth-shell-default intkey show test --url=http://rest-api3:8008
## You will notice that validator2 is not synchronizing blocks. In some cases one of other nodes might also stop synchronizing.{code}

 

*Error in logs*
{code:java}
Failed block validation: Block e15ba5457b67dc2b8e6b16d7ab5f45aae80df172a7f15449cdc47dcb55276c7726c1be97d3be6814e29c0b3569f1b76cee4422e05a4982c392abac7f47317338 (block_num:8, state:d4c837e061d5dbe1ea99cace6bd8d6756fabebdf4f753329b4936374e818333f, previous_block_id:9c25b1b571f2b9145c3f4cdafd0e7c48b2482f7b6d4cfbaadbbe4cabbf3692b266a1721979b11dff3c086dcf95d27e03a246ecb5cbbd271281c9ba2ac17db0d3) rejected due to missing predecessor 9c25b1b571f2b9145c3f4cdafd0e7c48b2482f7b6d4cfbaadbbe4cabbf3692b266a1721979b11dff3c086dcf95d27e03a246ecb5cbbd271281c9ba2ac17db0d3
{code}

column1: GossipMessage time_to_live is never decremented
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently every time, a block or batch is broadcasted, the message is created with the default starting time to live instead of the new decremented time to live. Note, Gossip Request message's time to live is correctly decremented. 

An optional  time_to_live parameter should be added to gossip broadcast_batch and broadcast_block and the new time_to_live value should be passed in and added to the GossipMessage. If the parameter is not given, the default/setting value should be used.

column1: validator degrades into more and more 429s
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When we send intkey transactions evenly spaced out at 10 txns/sec, over time the validators 429 more and more transactions and need to be restarted.

In more detail:

We have four machines in AWS running sawtooth validators, rest APIs, and a few transaction processors (tp_settings, intkey, block_info, validator registry).  Each of these processes is run in a separate docker container, all of them built from a recent master (sha 9ccff708ef5a20e236756089722825f0026934bd) using the sawtooth-core `bin/build_all -l python installed`.  We are running software poet (with the same configuration settings as the sawtooth-core poet-liveness test), and the parallel scheduler.

On one of the nodes, we are continually sending an intkey `incr` transaction with the key `foo` and then sleeping 0.1 seconds.  Everything seems fine until about one hour in, when we start seeing 429s  become more regular.  At about 5 hours it becomes rare to *not* get a 429 (maybe one success every 20 seconds).  If we stop firing these intkey transactions, wait a few hours, then try again, the validator is still immediately 429-ing most everything.  If we then restart the validator (just the one whose rest api we are targeting with intkey), everything is fine again for another couple hours, etc.

We have run this experiment at least 5 times over multiple builds from the latest master.

column1: Ping Requests Sent More Frequently than Interval
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
From a recent test run:
{code}
handlers Too many Pings (7.9253621101379395) in 10 seconds before authorization is complete: e984a2744a96e4aa86829f6b392a209086a578e02efedee42ea3761ef5
610a35ee23745526c5ac25a23a714d65a2457f04eefcfa9e7b4207b870235782ba51cc
...
handlers Too many Pings (5.77586555480957) in 10 seconds before authorization is complete: e984a2744a96e4aa86829f6b392a209086a578e02efedee42ea3761ef5610a35ee23745526c5ac25a23a714d65a2457f04eefcfa9e7b4207b870235782ba51cc
...
handlers Too many Pings (9.692877054214478) in 10 seconds before authorization is complete: e984a2744a96e4aa86829f6b392a209086a578e02efedee42ea3761ef5610a35ee23745526c5ac25a23a714d65a2457f04eefcfa9e7b4207b870235782ba51cc
{code}

This warning occurs between initiating and finalizing an authorization handshake.  When this fail, it triggers a hang-up of the potential peer connection. 

This is expected to be >= 10 seconds, as pings happen on a fixed loop of 10 seconds.

column1: StateDeltaSubscriberHandler does not handle missing event data well
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
In the file *rest_api/sawtooth_rest_api/state_delta_subscription_handler.py*, the member variable *_latest_state_delta_event* in the class *StateDeltaSubscriberHandler* can sometimes be set to *None* in situations that expect it to have type *ClientEventsGetResponse*.

For instance, on line 152 of that same file, an *AttributeError* will be raised if event is *None* (we sometimes encounter this).

column1: Raft Prototype
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Create a rust language based Raft implementation with the new consensus engine. It is highly desirable but not required that Bitwise IO use an existing Raft implementation (such as https://github.com/pingcap/tikv) as a library.

This prototype integration may not satisfy production criteria, and thus may not be suitable for production or LR testing. Bitwise IO shall design and document additional work required to make it production ready, suitable for community consumption.

The integration must be able to pass a liveness test similar to the existing PoET liveness test with 3 nodes.

column1: Chain Controller and Block Publisher Rust Conversion
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Port the Sawtooth Chain Controller and Block Publisher components from Python to Rust.  Additional components re-implemented in Rust for this effort may include: Block Validation, Completer, and Permission Verifier.

This change must pass LR1 and integration tests, to the same level as Sawtooth 1.0.
column91: Chain Controller and Block Publisher Rust Conversion

column1: State Pruning
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Implement State Pruning in the Merkle-Radix Tree Database.  This will limit the growth of the state database by removing old entries, and limiting growth to a recent number of state roots.  Growth will be a factor of number of addresses in state, not based around the number of blocks overall.

This work may require migration utilities.

This scope item includes the development of training content comparable to the existing content in the existing Hyperledger EdX course. The scope does not include the tasks associated with incorporating and republishing the course content or any other activities owned/driven by the Hyperledger organization. The scope does not include creation of videos.

column1: Sawtooth-Seth RPC unable to unlock alias
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
* OS 버전 : macOS High Sierra 10.13.3
 * 톱니 버전 : 1.0.1
 * 환경 세부 정보 (가상, 실제 등) : 12 GB RAM, 256 GB SSD, Docker 18.0.3
 * 재생산 단계 : sawtooth-seth 폴더에서 $ docker-compose를 실행하십시오 (또는 처음 인 경우) $ docker-up up --build. 모든 것이 정상적으로 작동하면 $ docker ps를 실행하여 seth-rpc의 컨테이너 ID를 얻습니다. 다른 터미널에서 컨테이너에 셸 
$ docker exec -it seth-rpc bash 
일단 다음 명령을 실행하십시오.

 # openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256k1 | openssl ec -out alias.pem -aes128
 # 세스 계정 가져 오기 alias.pem 별칭
 # seth 계정 만들기 --nonce = 0 - 기다림 별칭 
암호를 묻습니다 
.이 시점에서 별칭을 잠금 해제하여 seth-rpc를 시작하려고합니다. 
seth-rpc --unlock alias 
  
실제 결과 : 오류가 발생합니다. - 별칭 데이터 디렉토리에서 찾을 수 없습니다.

 * 예상 결과 - 별칭의 잠금을 해제해야합니다.
column39: MacOS High Sierra 10.13.3, Docker 18.0.3, Sawtooth-Seth 1.0.1
column135: 06/Apr/18 2:18 PM;DevB;Workaround suggested by Andrew Donald Kennedy.;;;
column137:
25/Apr/19 4:28 AM;danintel;Automated translation of Korean description:

OS version: macOS High Sierra 10.13.3
Sawtooth version: 1.0.1
Environmental details (virtual, physical, etc.): 12 GB RAM, 256 GB SSD, Docker 18.0.3
Reproduction: Run $ docker-compose in the sawtooth-seth folder (or the first time) $ docker-up up --build. If everything is working properly, run $ docker ps to get the container ID for seth-rpc. Shell in container at other terminal
$ docker exec -it seth-rpc bash
Run the following command once.
openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256k1 | openssl ec -out alias.pem -aes128
Get Seth account alias.pem alias
Create seth account --nonce = 0 - Wait alias
Ask for password
At this point, you want to unlock the alias to start seth-rpc.
seth-rpc --unlock alias
 
Actual Result: An error occurs. - Alias not found in data directory.
Expected Result - You must unlock the alias.;;;

column1: [Question] on immutability
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Hi all,

This may be a bit of a newbie question, and apologies for that.

I have played with Hyperledger Sawtooth and got the intkey demo successfully working with various SDK languages.

One of the things that I can see that the intkey demo can do is change the value associated with a given name as stored in the system state.

One of the things that I would be interested in is storing data in a completely immutable way in sawtooth. I understand that the blocks themselves are immutable, but IIUC the blocks aren't really used for storing data, but rather storing a reference to the data... 

It also possible to store data in an immutable way? 

Many thanks, 

David
column135: 15/May/18 7:38 PM;dbosschaert;Ping? Any thought around this?;;;
column136: 16/May/18 10:49 PM;boydjohnson;It would be possible to write immutability into the transaction processor. The check would be that if some object already exists in state, don't make a new one. Something similar is true in sawtooth-marketplace where if a user is created with a particular private/public key pair, no other user can be created with the same key-pair.;;;
column137:
16/May/18 11:40 PM;dbosschaert;Hi [~boydjohnson] thanks for your thoughts. This would be possible, but I guess it doesn't take advantage of the immutability of the blockchain. For me the key benefit of the blockchain is its immutable records. Especially when I'd like to prove that an event happened. 

If I have to implement the immutability in my own transaction processor then in what way do I take advantage of the blockchain immutability? Maybe I'm missing something, but I'd really like to be able to store my data on the blocks themselves so that they are guaranteed to be immutable. Is there an API I can use for that?;;;
column138: 08/Jun/18 9:52 PM;dbosschaert;Ping? Anyone an answer to my question? For me the key differentiator with using a blockchain implementation is the immutability guarantees. Do I have to implement that immutability myself in my tx processor? That seems odd to me... ;;;
column139:
09/Jun/18 3:01 AM;boydjohnson;Hi [~dbosschaert], So I think we view the Merkle state hash that is stored in the block as the immutable record, whereas what is in the actual Validator's state as more of a cache. So if someone were to audit intkey and block 1 had a transaction that sets "c" to 1 and block 2 has a transaction that sets "c" to 5, both transactions are stored in a block even though the current state as the transaction processor sees it "c" is 2.

You will probably get quicker responses at the #sawtooth channel on https://chat.hyperledger.org.;;;

column1: App Dev Docs for Transaction Processors is out of date

column38:
The Transaction Processor tutorials for both Python and Javascript (unsure about Java), use the 0.8 API for instantiating the TransactionHandler. They erroneously include encoding, which is no longer used, and for JS, list family versions as a string. It should be an array.

[https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/latest/_autogen/sdk_TP_tutorial_js.html#the-xohandler-class]
[https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/latest/_autogen/sdk_TP_tutorial_python.html#the-xotransactionhandler-class]

Might be worth give the rest of the document a once over for other 0.8 syntax as well.

column1: Implement Rust BlockValidator
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The BlockValidator validates that a block is valid beyond those checks that happen at other levels (such as signature verification in the Gossip layer). This includes all batches are valid and the resulting state hash matches the one in the block header, the block contains a predecessor in the current chain, there are no duplicate transactions or batches, all transaction dependencies are satisfied, settings stored in state are satisfied, and identity state is satisfied by signatures of batches and transactions.

The BlockValidator maintains the correctness that all of a block's predecessors must be validated before it is validated.

The BlockValidator is an active component.

But when query this transaction status, it will always be "PENDING", I think it should be "INVALID". Here is the minimum code snippet to reproduce it: https://gist.github.com/ailisp/6293ebdac7d6a07c33d55c0ed33b03c7

column1: Invalid Batches sometimes return "pending" status when queried
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Under certain conditions a Batch rejected by the validator is inappropriately given a status of "PENDING". It is possible to trigger this condition by submitting a Transaction with an invalid input address (specifically one that does not match the hexadecimal format), and then querying the `/batch_statuses` endpoint after the validator rejects it.

This can be demonstrated with this python script from [~ailisp], who originally reported the issue:
 [https://gist.github.com/ailisp/6293ebdac7d6a07c33d55c0ed33b03c7]

Steps to reproduce:
 - From sawtooth-core run `docker-compose -f docker/compose/sawtooth-default.yaml up`
 - Save above script to `test.py`
 - Run `python test.py`

You should see logs similar to this:

{{sawtooth-validator-default | [2018-04-26 21:41:03.874 INFO     executor] Exception creating context: Address or namespace asdfsfasfss listed in inputs is not valid}}{{sawtooth-validator-default | [2018-04-26 21:41:03.974 DEBUG    publisher] Batch 94d20adbcf7a2eb8abf9b22b5dbdac5754af424b7a0232ef69cf3e5201406b1914985b2010091b12fdae229585ad076a2381bcd37121403623896830645a7405 invalid, not added to block.}}

Running `curl localhost:8008/batch_statuses?id=<id from logs>` should confirm the logs from the script. The batch is still pending.

column1: ztest scalability issues
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
This ticket is coming in the context of experiencing hard times with the ztest in a network of 4 validators. What we would experience is having validators freezing. Looking into the current implementation of the ztest, I found several lines of code that are troubling while trying to figure out what the ztest is doing. Maybe the most questionable part is discovering that validators, when they perform the ztest, will inspect almost each block published onchain to this date to decide if the a block pass the ztest or not.

Reproducibility: based on the branch https://github.com/benoitrazet/sawtooth-core/tree/ztest-scalability-issues

run the test_poet_liveness with

`./bin/run_docker_test test_poet_liveness`

monitor the logs of the second validator to see the number blocks inspected to decide the ztest. This number is incrementally increasing as the chain grows:

`docker logs latest_validator-2_1 2>&1 | grep "zTest succeeded"`

!Screen Shot 2018-04-27 at 3.28.26 PM.png|width=424,height=53!

What is striking here is `zTest succeeded with depth 389` which indicates that the validator has been going through 389 blocks to decide that the candidate block is valid. Things only get worse when the number of blocks increase.

The lines of code that are relevant for this issue are:

https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/289dce37db23f58427606f572980ac6eade748e8/consensus/poet/core/sawtooth_poet/poet_consensus/consensus_state.py#L366

https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/289dce37db23f58427606f572980ac6eade748e8/consensus/poet/core/sawtooth_poet/poet_consensus/consensus_state.py#L891

This problem seems to be related to another bug we observed in the following ticket:

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-1121

Might be a good time to revisit the ztest code. I'd be happy to do it but after spending several hours experimenting and looking into the code, I feel I am missing a part of the story about the ztest by just looking at the resource available to figure this out.

column1: Add unit test code coverage reporting for Rust components
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Add unit test code coverage reporting for Rust components.  Reporting should be equivalent to that currently available for Python, e.g built into the build process.

One possible approach that appears to have traction in the Rust community is kcov. 

The project is located here:  [https://simonkagstrom.github.io/kcov/]

There is a recent tutorial here: [http://sunjay.ca/2016/07/25/rust-code-coverage]

...and an earlier tutorial here: [https://users.rust-lang.org/t/tutorial-how-to-collect-test-coverages-for-rust-project/650]

If this has significant impact on build time, then it should be implemented as a build-time switch and executed on nightly build, so that current metrics are available while not impacting PR builds.

column1: Add method for creating private key from hex to signing contexts
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The ideal workflow for the signing modules is to use the `_create_context_` method of _CryptoFactory_ with the string "_secp256k1_" in order to create a _Secp256k1Context_ which can generate keys and provide signing functionality. The advantage of using a string and not directly instantiating the underlying classes is it is very config friendly, and could be easily expanded to other signing algorithms in the future.

Unfortunately, this workflow currently only works if generating a _new_ private key using the `new_random_private_key` method. There is no method on _Context_ objects to generate a new _PrivateKey_ from either existing bytes or a hex string. This means that the _Secp256k1PrivateKey_ class must be imported and instantiated directly in order to use its `_from_hex_` method with existing private keys. This defeats the purpose of having a _CryptoFactory_.

I propose adding a few new methods to complete the workflow, and make it possible to use the _CryptoFactory_ as intended:

PrivateKey.from_bytes(bytes) -> PrivateKey

Context.new_private_key_from_bytes(self, bytes) -> PrivateKey

Context.new_private_key_from_hex(self, string) -> PrivateKey
column136:
07/May/18 2:22 PM;delventhalz;I picked hex and bytes because they seemed agnostic. While hex is preferable, I am happy to go with just bytes if hex seems too opinionated. However, loading a previously generated private key is a fundamental aspect of any use case I've implemented. Without that feature, any workflow is not usable in the applications I've built.

Not sure I follow the second point. The implementation would come from the Context:
_CryptoFactory.create_context('secp256k1') -> Secp256k1Context_
_Secp256k1Context.new_private_key_from_bytes(privkey) -> Secp256k1PrivateKey_

Currently I am skipping the CryptoFactory entirely because I have to hardcode the private key instance anyway:
_secp256k1.Secp256k1Context() -> Secp256k1Context_
_secp256k1.Secp256k1PrivateKey.from_hex(privkey) -> Secp256k1PrivateKey_;;;

column1: add poet fork resolve
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
PoET objects (block publisher, fork resolver, and block verifier) start up with a block cache, a batch publisher, and a state view factory. In the consensus engine, these objects will have to be substituted with proxies, which will return the necessary information using consensus service calls (except for the batch publisher, which will communicate using a client endpoint).

 

Note that implementing the block cache proxy entails implementing a block store proxy as well, since that is exposed as a block cache interface. The proxy state view factory should produce proxy state views.

column1: Encrypt data at rest
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
_*Problem statement*_:

Encrypting data in the TP and writing to state was our first thought however; as the TP may/will be called more than once (Publish/Verify/Etc.) good encryption will produce different encrypted data and thus fail in the validator. This applies not just for single validator/TP but is exacerbated in a validator network.

 

_*Improvement:*_

Enable encrypt/decrypt to/from state while not violating the hash generation for validator comparison.

Have ability for application to pass the encryption 'key' aligned by family namespace/version.

column1: pyformance sends nan values to influxdb
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Pyformance on certain occasions, sends nan values instead of 0.
This happens everytime, consistently if python values of metrics vars are None or undefined.
Influxdb is unable to parse nan.

As of today, pyformance doesn't have such abilities to filter out or substitute 0 for None. Either we have to change our code to ensure we don't send None values to pyformance or replace the pyformance with a library that does the filtering at client side or add an extra library like Kapacitor at influxdb server side.

Here's a sample log of the response from influxdb:
Content-Length: 588
Connection: close

{"error":"partial write: unable to parse 'sawtooth_validator.completer.Completer.incomplete_batches_length,host=ubuntu-desktop value=nan 1521708718': invalid number\nunable to parse 'sawtooth_validator.chain.ChainController.block_num,host=ubuntu-desktop value=nan 1521708718': invalid number\nunable to parse 'sawtooth_validator.completer.Completer.seen_txns_length,host=ubuntu-desktop value=nan 1521708718': invalid number\nunable to parse 'sawtooth_validator.completer.Completer.incomplete_blocks_length,host=ubuntu-desktop value=nan 1521708718': invalid number dropped=0"}

column1: Improve consistency of SDK Documentation cover page

column1: port 3030: Connection refused | docker-compose.yaml with seth-rpc
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
port 3030: Connection refused

After
\{\{$ git clone [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth] }}
 {{$ cd sawtooth-seth}}
 \{\{ $ docker-compose -f docker-compose.yaml up}}

Run test 
{{$ curl [http://0.0.0.0:3030|http://0.0.0.0:3030/] -d '\{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "id": 1, "method": "eth_blockNumber"}' -H "Content-Type: application/json"}}

Result
 port 3030: Connection refused

##

In trying to resolve we noticed "From Docker 18.03 onwards our recommendation is to connect to the special DNS name {{host.docker.internal}}, which resolves to the internal IP address used by the host. This is for development purpose and will not work in a production environment outside of Docker for Mac. [https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/networking/#use-cases-and-workarounds]

Related for Linux I found [https://github.com/docker/for-linux/issues/264]

##

Chatted with hosts of Tuesday (June 12th) session of the "The Hyperledger Sawtooth Application Developers Forum". Who advised to try removal of line 131 from docker-compose.yaml 

This resulted in 

//lines skipped for brevity

seth-rpc | thread 'main' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: AddrParseError(())', libcore/result.rs:945:5
 sawtooth-validator | [2018-06-12 14:23:26.190 INFO path] Skipping path loading from non-existent config file: /etc/sawtooth/path.toml
 seth-rpc | note: Run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` for a backtrace.

// lines skipped for brevity

seth-cli | creating key directory: /root/.sawtooth/keys
 seth-cli | writing file: /root/.sawtooth/keys/root.priv
 seth-cli | writing file: /root/.sawtooth/keys/root.pub
 seth-rpc exited with code 101

With line 131 seth-rpc loads w/o error (but Ports are refused).

column1: REST API /subscriptions sends old deltas
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When using web sockets to subscribe to `/subscriptions` on the REST API, a client will immediately receive the state delta for the most recent block. This is counter-intuitive as the subscription _should_ be for all _new_ deltas. The most recent block may in fact be quite old.

 

This also conflicts with the guidance in the documentation:

_"If you are interested in the state prior to the point of subscription, you should fetch the values of state via the REST API's /state endpoint."_

 

If you first fetch from `/state`, and then attempt to combine it with subscription data, you will double whatever data was in the most recent block. Clients will have to take the extra step of filtering their data for uniqueness or dropping the first delta the receive.

column1: Post batch with  Signer Public Key as string is not responding
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Step to reproduce:
1. Create a signer key object for the transaction.
2. Use string as a signer key instead of hex value.
3. Validator gives parse error for string as a input.
[sawtooth_signing.core.ParseError: Unable to parse public key: Non-hexadecimal digit found]

Additional Information: 

1. Error Message Handled properly in below scenarios:-
 When Signer key is not converted to hex value, then the post operation is failed and type error is produced. 

 def create_batch(transactions,signer,public_key):
        transaction_signatures = [t.header_signature for t in transactions]

        header = BatchHeader(
            signer_public_key=public_key,
>           transaction_ids=transaction_signatures)
E       TypeError: <sawtooth_signing.secp256k1.Secp256k1PublicKey object at 0x7f64cdc7a588> has type Secp256k1PublicKey, but expected one of: bytes, unicode

utils.py:324: TypeError


2. Error not Handled properly in below scenarios:-
When Public signer key is a string then the Validator/Rest Api time out

column1: batch with no transactions causes endless loop in validator publisher
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Bug reported by TASE.

Post empty batch without any transactions, the validator log is entering endless loop of the following print:
 [2018-06-28 14:31:54.405 DEBUG publisher] Abandoning block (1, S:, P:9f12a491): no batches added

 

following are the steps to reproduce:
 * edit [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/sdk/examples/intkey_python/sawtooth_intkey/client_cli/create_batch.py]

remove following strikethrough lines:

def create_batch(transactions, signer):
 transaction_signatures = [t.header_signature for t in transactions]

header = batch_pb2.BatchHeader(
 signer_public_key=signer.get_public_key().as_hex(),
 -transaction_ids=transaction_signatures-)

header_bytes = header.SerializeToString()

signature = signer.sign(header_bytes)

batch = batch_pb2.Batch(
 header=header_bytes,
 -transactions=transactions,-
 header_signature=signature)

return batch

 
 * run sudo python3 setup.py install
 * run intkey create_batch and load

column1: Unpredictable state root hash mismatch error on Validator
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
I have setup a {{Hyperlder Sawtooth Network}} from the {{Sawtooth Docs}}, you can find {{docker-compose.yaml}} I used [official guide|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/1.0/app_developers_guide/sawtooth-default.yaml] to setup the network.
 * Transaction Processor Code [https://gist.github.com/rohitkhatri/04bb90c531385d8825c5243773d6a269]
 * Validator log: [https://justpaste.it/74y5g]
 * Transaction processor log: [https://justpaste.it/5ayn6]

The Validator works absolutely fine for couple of hours and then suddenly it gives the `state root hash mismatch error` post which, the validator doesn't reach out to Transaction Processor for any further transactions. I am not using PoET

If I restart the entire network again, things fall in the same loop of errors after few hours.
column39:
* Sawtooth 1.0.4
 * Docker containers on Ubuntu 16.04
 * One Validator
 * One Transaction Processor
column135: 09/Jul/18 2:29 PM;ThoughtChimp;The issue was with different state bcoz of using JSON for the payload. We changed that and it got sorted.;;;

column1: /GET State returns empty data property without address namespace prefix
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
While quering GET/State with address without namespace prefix it was noticed that it  gives empty data property

*Steps to reproduce*:
 # Run validator and other services.
 # Start posting the batches.
 # Use curl to query the state without namespace in address parameter               

eg:-   

Intkey prefix  :-   *1cf126*

state address -   1cf12631610968105b4b59c2ea2f17e872a5277e65ebbd97d23c15d314e0b95e9a5bb1

Remove the prefix part and use curl 

curl [http://localhost:8008/state?address=|http://localhost:8008/state?head=]"31610968105b4b59c2ea2f17e872a5277e65ebbd97d23c15d314e0b95e9a5bb1"

*Error in logs:*

Please check attachment

*Actual behavior*: It gives empty data property in response along with head, link and paging parameters

*Expected behavior:* A json response with error code 75 should be returned

column1: Have single store of reference counts in BlockManager
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Instead of the BlockManager having Anchors and RefBlock and that blocks in the "main cache" or Pool are RefBlocks, there should be a single container of references and references and blocks are stored separately.

column1: Add reference counting increments and decrements to BlockManager Iterators
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: When a block is returned by next in the Iterator, the next block should have its reference count increased so that it cannot be unreffed. This guarantees that the Iterator has all the blocks that are going to be iterated through without having to access all of them at once.

column1: Avoid broken links for file renames/deletes in Sawtooth doc
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Research, scope, and implement a way to avoid broken links when changing file names and internal links (section title) in updated/reorganized doc content.  For example, if a doc file is renamed (when the title changes) or deleted, anyone who bookmarked that topic should not get a broken link. Instead, they should be redirected to the replacement file or next best option in the doc (which could be the intro/contents page).

This task requires technical help from someone who understands how sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs is set up.

column1: Seth-rpc exits after three smart contract call transactions
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Steps to reproduce:
 # Download latest seth from here ([https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth]) and run it with docker-compose.yaml.--
 # Create an external account, <account>
 # Write a Smart Contract, compile it, and get the <binary>
 # Use a node.js server app with web.3js as a required module (web3.js version used: v1.0.0-beta.30)
 # Deploy a smart contract as a Contract creation transaction, using web3.eth.sendTransaction(\{"from": <account>,"data": <binary>})
 # Call the smart contract, using a Contract call transaction as follows web3.eth.sendTransaction(\{"from": <account>, "data": <input_data>, "to": <contract-address>}
 # In the first contract call transaction, in the console where docker-compose.yaml runs,  the following error appears: _seth-rpc container thread '<unnamed> panicked at 'index 32 out of range for slice of length 0', libcore/slice/[mod.rs:785|http://mod.rs:785/]:5_, see also the screenshot _error-1.png_ attached.
 # In the second contract call transaction, same error with Step 7 appears in the console
 # In the third contract call transaction, seth-rpc crashes and exits with code 0, see screenshot _error-2.png_ attached.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

Would you be able to either provide the contract that you're experiencing this with, provide another screenshot with {{RUST_BACKTRACE=1}} added to [this line|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/blob/master/docker-compose.yaml#L134] in {{docker-compose.yml}}, or both?;;;
column136:
26/Jul/18 4:02 PM;anastath;[^stack-trace.txt]

Hi, I'm attaching the stack trace when running docker-compose.yaml with the option RUST_BACKTRACE=1 added to the line 134.

We encountered this issue with different smart contracts, so it seems that the problem is not tailored to the smart contract used.

UPDATE: *The problem must be related with the version of web3.js used*. I could reproduce the problem with web3@1.0.0-beta.34, but could not reproduce the problem with web3@0.20.6

 ;;;

I cross checked on the source deployed on my PC that the change in this commit ([https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/commit/0ff7164b9faf36bb43bbbca2f85f12cc5acb28f7#diff-961caa7dd651e71f1a60c1769920758c]) is included. So, this problem does persist after this commit.;;;

column1: signer_public_key is kept on the chain
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Is the signer_public_key values needed post Batch/Transaction processing? Keeping them on the chain (and visible via `/batches`, `/blocks` and/or `/transactions` endpoint is a privacy loop-hole.

If there is no post-transaction usage needed for the operation of sawtooth then they should be removed and not part of the chain.

column1: Block response is not updating paging parameters (limit and start) properly.
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Pre-condition:* All required services running in background (validator, intkey, restapi and settings tp).

*Actual behavior:* Block response is not updating paging parameters (limit and start) properly.

*Expected behavior:* Block response should update with paging parameters (limit and start) properly.

*Step to recreate the issue:*
 - Run the services
 - Post batches
 - Try to access blocks with start and limit as a parameter.

Rest API response is updating only for “start” (first) in paging field and Limit (second) is set to default value null (Limit is not updated with 100).

Response is not closing/exiting normally as compare to single parameter (eg. Curl [http://localhost:8008/blocks?start=0x0000000000000000]).

Run: curl [http://localhost:8008/blocks?start=0x0000000000000000&limit=100].

Attached -> Paging_param.png

To test in different combination, switched start and limit parameters and identified first parameter (limit) is only updating

Attached -> Verify_issue.png

Running Rest API response:

Attached -> Rest API Response.png

column1: All transactions stay pending after receiving txn with unkown family_name
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*Description*

The validator would not process more transactions after he receives a transaction with an unknown family_name.

*Impact*

This behavior is problematic because it has the effect of freezing a validator. Nevertheless, when the `sawtooth.validator.transaction_families` is used everything is good 

*Reproducibility*

This is reproducible no matter what validator is used (python 1.0.4 or python+rust latest master) and no matter what consensus is used devmode/software_poet/devmode_rust

To reproduce it, deploy a network with a given transaction family, run a few transactions, verify they are good, change the name of the family_name, send some transactions with the modified family_name, change back the family_name to its correct version, the transactions stay in the `PENDING` state (according to the REST api).

column1: backpressure never ends
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
queue size doesn't have a minimum.

running sawtooth 1.0.5 on one node with intkey TP

cretead simple script that is using intkey workload to send 10 txns per second and every 20 seconds send 100 txns per second for 2 seconds.

the expected result is that during the peak lots of txns will be rejected but after peak we should go back to normal.

what happens is that because of peaks the journal queue gets smaller and smaller, causing validator to reject more transaction than needed.

see attached validator log from stress, line 3952 for example, applying back pressure when there are only 7 txns in the Q:
[32m[2018-09-05 16:36:58.665 INFO back_pressure_handlers][0m [37mApplying back pressure on client submitted batches: current depth: 7, limit: 6.8[0m
column39: NUC with sawtooth installed from stable repo.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135:
01/Sep/18 12:10 AM;benoit.razet;I'm experiencing a similar problem on a network of 4 nodes with sawtooth 1.0.5: when the backpressure kicks in, it is never released and the validator don't accept new batches, though he still able to process blocks.

Something noticeable too, is that when the back pressure kicks in on one node, it propagates to the other nodes at the next batch they receive.;;;
column137: 06/Sep/18 1:52 PM;mithun2679;[~yoni] can you please upload the script you mention in your comment.;;;
column138:
06/Sep/18 2:20 PM;yoni;[~mithun2679] see script below, you can play with the numbers to improve reproduction rate, the more pressure on the TP/validator the more likely to see the problem, on some iterations i saw the queue limit was down to 2

#!/bin/bash
for((i=1;i<=10;++i)) do
 echo "loop iteration $i started"
 intkey workload --rate 10 -d 5 &
 sleep 15
 kill -9 %% 
 intkey workload --rate 150 -d 2 &
 sleep 3
 kill -9 %% 
 echo "loop iteration $i completed"
done;;;

column1: Allow read several addresses once from TP by using address prefix
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135: 02/Nov/18 1:48 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;[~yoni] Can you please describe the motivation for the requested feature? What is the use case that benefits from retrieving a branch of state? And is it exclusively discovering the presence or absence of a node? Or is it also retrieving the data at that node?;;;
column136:
06/Nov/18 4:14 AM;yoni;The motivation came when looking for a way to improve processing transaction logic by making better use of the radix merkle tree. 
trying to show an example without getting too much into  our complicated TP logic: let's say we want to add to intkey TP a transaction that will trigger delete all keys with key name with certain length.


one approach will be to store in a special address a list of all key names length, but now for every new key TP will need to update this address, this could be expensive especially when this address data gets huge.
a small improvement could come by bucketing keys based on their length but the performance is still not ideal if there are a very big number of keys. all the solutions we considered had its own problems.


the approach we finally decided we would like to use and think would be the best is to use the optimization that comes from using the radix tree. Add prefix for each key address with the key name length. to do an action on all keys that have certain length, we would read all relevant address by prefix. because addresses are in a radix tree, reading a lot of addresses by prefix is much faster than reading the same amount of addresses one by one. there is no need to store list of used keys in a special address.

since we only want to delete the addresses we found we are not interested in the data of these addresses, if read by prefix only returned the list of addresses without the data, the performance would be even better.

this is more or less our motivation for this request, we think that others could also gain from both being able to read by prefix or from detecting if nodes exists.;;;
column137:
13/Nov/18 10:46 PM;benoit.razet;Just a couple of thoughts, looking into the proposed idea through the specific criterion of computing resources: in the current design, it looks to me (tell me if I’m wrong) that the relationship between the size of a TP request and the amount of computational process time required by the validator to process this request is arguably linear (maybe the constant is not so small), but not unbounded and not exponential. I think this property is desirable for different reasons including security (limited attack vector of TP on validator), performance (all users share the validator resources, so better control the cost of TP requests) and iii) simplicity (well identified good TP programming practice). For this reason, I’m skeptical of having a `context.get_state` that takes a prefix and returns all the addresses existing. I can see how on the other side extending `context.delete_state` with a prefix address would be more acceptable because deleting a subtree in a radix Merkle Tree can be done in constant time (ignoring the cost of freeing memory).

In the intkey motivating example, I don’t really see the problem with the bucketed solution the way it is presented. Nevertheless I see that the bucketed solution could be problematic if concurrent users are allowed to submit intkey transactions, in this case it would be challenging for a user to delete a set of keys of a certain length because it would be impossible to determine for sure the set keys the txn will meet in during its execution.;;;

column1: Executor does not wait to resubmit a Transaction if the TP Crashes
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
If the transaction processor crashes during execution, the executor will resolve the future with an internal error. The transaction is then resubmitted automatically like all internal errors but since there is no matching transaction processor for the transaction, the transaction is never processed and can lock up the scheduler.

This can be reproduced by adding a syntax error into the python intkey tp and submitted a transaction against a validator running a serial scheduler. Once the tp dies, fix the issues and relaunch the tp. Submit a new transaction and you will see it hang.

 

Either more options for types of Internal Errors should be added or proper waiting for a matching tp to be present should be verified.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

If Transaction processor is crashed, restarted and renamed, then executor/ scheduler not allow to submit the transaction.
In logs, executor hang with below trace:
*[2018-10-12 15:53:34.852 [Thread-64] executor INFO] Waiting for transaction processor (intkey, 1.0)*

Issue is similar to STL-1167, STL-1373 and STL-1450.;;;

column1: Revamping of the Java SDK
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
To better accomodate parallel development, tests and evaluation on changes, and create a multi-threaded solution, I suggest a change on the current format of the project.

   A multi-tiered Maven project would help in this, give the following:
 *   A parent POM, holding common artifacts, plugins and dependencies versions, building and configuration parameters, etc
 * Initially, the following modules:
 ** Commons : will hold the crypto settings and operations, marshall/unmarshall of messages, general utilities;
 ** Transaction Processor: hold the ZeroMQ setup and behavior, interfaces, messaging pipelines, etc;
 ** REST modules, initially based in Jersey : handle the REST elements and operations needed to interact with the validators

 

   Since Java 9 is EOL, and 8 will be next year ([Oracle roadmap|http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/eol-135779.html]) the SDK would use Java 10.

   The use of TestNG on tests will be preferred over JUnit to reuse the tests results.

 

    There's a [runnable code base|https://github.com/CarvalhoLeonardo/sawtooth-sdk-java/tree/development] that I intend to do layered PRs on the project, to furthr evaluation of my ideas. Please give all feedback you can.

column1: Transaction executor wait invariably to post batches
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Validator transaction executor wait invariably to post batches.

Steps to recreate bug.

1. Started services validator, settings-tp, intkey-tp and sawtooth-rest-api.
 2. Modified the transaction family name from “intkey” to “abcdef”.
 3. Posted batches 
 4. Response took approx. 5 min and posted batch in pending state.
 5. Changed family name back to “intkey”. 
 6. Posted batch with transaction family name as “intkey”. 
 7. Further posted batches for intkey TP, remain in pending status.
 8. “abcdef” transaction processor wait invariably. Intkey TP to post batches is not allowed.

Configured the validator for parallel transaction execution.
 Validator Transaction executor should handle any miss behavior from transaction processor (Traffic generator/ Intkey).

column1: Seth RPC contact deploy transaction unsuccessful
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Seth RPC contact deploy transaction is unsuccessful. Below are the steps to reproduce the bug

docker exec -it seth-cli-go bash. Commands executed in seth-cli-go container to create key and account

openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256k1 | openssl ec -out mykeyfile.pem
 seth account import mykeyfile.pem myalias
 seth account create --nonce=0 --wait myalias

seth account list
 myalias2: 2befd96ce96af926aee64e8c702493e12be65b23

cp contracts/examples/simple_intkey/simple_intkey.sol contracts/contract.sol

solc --bin contract.sol -> Generate the  blob of hex-encoded bytes 

docker exec -it seth-rpc bash. execute below command in seth-rpc container

seth-rpc --connect tcp://validator:4004 --bind 0.0.0.0:3030 --unlock myalias

execute  below command from your linux terminal

curl -d '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "eth_sendTransaction", "id": 2, "params": [{"from": "0x

{address}

", "data": "0x\{contract}"}]}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" localhost:3030

 

and in the result I get a transaction ID in result as

{"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":"0xcd90ed04b886f0e862c978a82893e8000aa59fe20430589dfdb76a26fc11c74f65d16b5376a7118572b4d10f52cf7ee0d82132b800a63a417715ff7f6b786a78","id":2}

But when I call “eth_getTransactionReceipt”  with above getting null result

curl -d '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "eth_getTransactionReceipt", "id": 3, "params": ["0xcd90ed04b886f0e862c978a82893e8000aa59fe20430589dfdb76a26fc11c74f65d16b5376a7118572b4d10f52cf7ee0d82132b800a63a417715ff7f6b786a78"]}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" localhost:3030

 

{"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":null,"id":3}

The above transaction to deploy the contract is also not submitted in blockchain since [http://localhost:8080/transactions/cd90ed04b886f0e862c978a82893e8000aa59fe20430589dfdb76a26fc11c74f65d16b5376a7118572b4d10f52cf7ee0d82132b800a63a417715ff7f6b786a78|http://localhost:8080/transactions/]?

 gives error message : "There is no transaction with the id specified in the blockchain.",

There are no messages in seth-rpc container when contract gets deployed
