It looks like you're trying to create a contract account without any permissions specified or global permissions set. To fix this, you could try either specifying permissions in the call you're making to create a contract account, or setting global permissions.;;;
column136:
10/Oct/18 5:47 PM;manojgop;When I execute  seth show account 2befd96ce96af926aee64e8c702493e12be65b23, I see all permissions are enabled.

Address: 2befd96ce96af926aee64e8c702493e12be65b23
 Balance: 0
 Code :
 Nonce : 1
 Perms : +root,+send,+call,+contract,+account
 (No Storage Set)

As per documentation, if a permission is not set, account permissions default to those set at the global permissions address. Also if no permissions are set at the global permissions address, all permissions are allowed.

 Also if I create contact using “seth contract create --wait \{alias} \{contract}” it’s working fine. Only when I use JSON RPC I’m facing issue in deploying contract. 

 

What is the command to set permissions with JSON RPC. I’m referring to documentation in [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/seth/releases/latest/dapps.html#deploying-contracts]

And below is the command I found in the documentation to deploy contact. I could  not find any permission field

 curl -d '{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "eth_sendTransaction", "id": 2, "params": [{"from": "0x

{address}", "data": "0x\{contract}"}]}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" localhost:3030

 

 ;;;
column137:
10/Oct/18 11:57 PM;knkski;[~manojgop]: You are probably using the code from this branch, which has an updated version of Burrow that introduces the panic:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/pull/73]

The documentation has not yet been updated, since that PR hasn't yet been merged into master, as there's an open bug in Burrow to fix it:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/burrow/issues/908]

You'll have to either specify permissions in the RPC call (which the CLI does for you, which is why that works), or switch back to the master branch of Seth, which uses a version of Burrow that doesn't panic.;;;

column139: 11/Oct/18 11:56 PM;knkski;[~manojgop]: It's quite possible that you're using a docker container with that branch still in it. Can you copy/paste the entire output from the {{docker-compose}} command here, as you try the above steps?;;;
column140:
15/Oct/18 1:24 PM;manojgop;version: '3'

services:
 seth-cli-go:
 build:
 context: .
 dockerfile: ./cli-go/Dockerfile
 args:
 - ISOLATION_ID=${ISOLATION_ID}
 - http_proxy
 - https_proxy
 - no_proxy
 image: sawtooth-seth-cli-go:${ISOLATION_ID}
 container_name: seth-cli-go
 volumes:
 - ./contracts:/project/sawtooth-seth/contracts
 - sawtooth:/root/.sawtooth
 depends_on:
 - rest-api
 working_dir: /project/sawtooth-seth
 entrypoint: |
 bash -c "
 seth init http://rest-api:8080 &&
 if [ ! -f /root/.sawtooth/keys/root.priv ]; then
 sawtooth keygen
 fi;
 tail -f /dev/null
 "

seth-tp:
 build:
 context: .
 dockerfile: ./processor/Dockerfile
 args:
 - ISOLATION_ID=${ISOLATION_ID}
 - http_proxy
 - https_proxy
 - no_proxy
 image: sawtooth-seth-tp:${ISOLATION_ID}
 container_name: seth-tp
 depends_on:
 - validator
 command: |
 bash -c "
 seth-tp -vv \
 -C tcp://validator:4004
 "

block-info-tp:
 image: hyperledger/sawtooth-block-info-tp:1.0
 container_name: block-info-tp
 depends_on:
 - validator
 command: block-info-tp -vv --connect tcp://validator:4004

settings-tp:
 image: hyperledger/sawtooth-settings-tp:1.0
 container_name: settings-tp
 depends_on:
 - validator
 command: settings-tp -vv --connect tcp://validator:4004

rest-api:
 image: hyperledger/sawtooth-rest-api:1.0
 container_name: rest-api
 ports:
 - '8080:8080'
 depends_on:
 - validator
 entrypoint: |
 sawtooth-rest-api -vv
 --connect tcp://validator:4004
 --bind rest-api:8080

validator:
 image: hyperledger/sawtooth-validator:1.0
 container_name: sawtooth-validator
 ports:
 - '4004:4004/tcp'
 - 8800
 command: |
 bash -c "
 if [ ! -f /etc/keys/validator.priv ]; then
 sawadm keygen &&
 sawset genesis \
 -k /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv \
 -o config-genesis.batch &&
 sawset proposal create \
 -k /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv \
 sawtooth.validator.batch_injectors=block_info \
 -o config.batch &&
 sawadm genesis config-genesis.batch config.batch
 fi;
 sawtooth-validator -vv \
 --endpoint tcp://validator:8800 \
 --bind component:tcp://eth0:4004 \
 --bind network:tcp://eth0:8800
 "

seth-rpc:
 build:
 context: .
 dockerfile: ./rpc/Dockerfile
 args:
 - ISOLATION_ID=${ISOLATION_ID}
 - http_proxy
 - https_proxy
 - no_proxy
 image: sawtooth-seth-rpc:${ISOLATION_ID}
 container_name: seth-rpc
 volumes:
 - sawtooth:/root/.sawtooth
 depends_on:
 - validator
 ports:
 - 3030:3030
 command: |
 bash -c "
 seth-rpc --connect tcp://validator:4004 --bind 0.0.0.0:3030
 "

volumes:
 sawtooth:;;;

column1: Can't determine when transactions fail via Seth RPC
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When I submit a transaction which ultimately fails due to {{REVERT}} or some other reason, the transaction receipt is never retrievable.

 

Reproduction steps:
 # Ensure you have nodejs v8.2 or later installed.
 # Install truffle with {{npm install -g truffle@beta}}
 # Clone the project at [https://github.com/benjamincburns/seths-petshop] 
 # run {{npm install}} in the cloned project to install dependencies
 # Edit {{truffle-config.js}} to point at your Seth RPC endpoint.
 # Ensure that one or more accounts is unlocked by running seth's RPC with the `--unlock` flag.
 # Run `truffle compile && truffle migrate` to compile and deploy the project's contracts
 # Run {{DEBUG='SethProvider:RPC' truffle test}}

 

The project contains only one test which is designed to trigger a {{REVERT}}. You'll notice in the debug output that Truffle tries over and over to fetch a single transaction receipt, but the `eth_getTransactionReceipt` for that call always returns `null`.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135: 12/Oct/18 7:48 AM;benjamincburns;I think the bug is [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/blob/master/processor/src/seth_tp/handler/handler.go#L105-L108]. Notice that if an error occurs the handler never issues a transaction receipt. Then at line 114 if there is no error from the TransactionHandler, a receipt is created.;;;
column136: 24/Oct/18 10:53 AM;benjamincburns;PR submitted to address this issue: https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/pull/77;;;

column1: Raft panics on invalid transaction
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column39:
Tested with several transaction processors and several consensus modules, both in Docker on Linux and on real hardware. The simplest thing to do is run a single-node raft and issue any invalid transaction to a transaction processor. Here's a {{panic.yaml}} that demonstrates it using the [Configuring and Deploying|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/raft/nightly/master/configuring_deploying.html] instructions, assuming you add {{shell}} to the list of images to build from {{sawtooth-core}}.
{code:java}
version: "3.6"

networks:
  rest_apis:
    external:
      name: raft_rest_apis

volumes:
  raft_shared_data:
    external: true

services:

  shell:
    image: sawtooth-shell
    volumes:
      - raft_shared_data:/shared_data
    networks:
      default:
      rest_apis:
    command: "bash -c \"\
      sawadm keygen root && mkdir -p $$HOME/.sawtooth/keys && mv /etc/sawtooth/keys/root.* $$HOME/.sawtooth/keys; \
      export TARGET=$$(ls /shared_data/rest_apis -1 | head -n 1); \
      sleep 10; \
      intkey set foo 0 --url http://$${TARGET}:8008; \
      intkey set foo 0 --url http://$${TARGET}:8008
    \""
{code}

column136: 13/Oct/18 12:31 AM;ltseeley;Hi! Thanks for reporting this bug. Have you been able to consistently reproduce this error by submitting invalid intkey transactions?;;;
column137: 13/Oct/18 12:52 AM;kirkwood;Yes, we have. It might not be obvious, but there's a YAML file for the {{adhoc}} stuff up in the environment section in this ticket that demonstrates it. It's not specific to {{intkey}}, though; any invalid txn from any TP seems to do it, and we first noticed it with our own. Following the latest [Configuring and Deploying|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/raft/nightly/master/configuring_deploying.html] instructions and using the {{intkey}} shell in the {{adhoc}} YAML above is just the simplest repro I could come up with.;;;

column1: Add protobuf UNSET field clarification to documentation
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Our protobufs include a placeholder enum value (some variation of "UNSET") to avoid default assignment and errors that could arise from that. 

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/commit/014a775c2094e27b1d1b4114aaebacaca195cff4]

The docs could be updated with a note to point out the intended use of this value. i.e. it is not a type or an operation itself and that failing to explicitly set one of the remaining values for the field will cause the transaction to fail. 

Here is an example area in the Identity Transaction Family doc where the note could be placed but the unset field is used in a variety of places as indicated in the commit linked above).

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blame/master/docs/source/transaction_family_specifications/identity_transaction_family.rst#L48]

column1: Rest query for an invalid transaction to show rejected reason
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Requested by TASE.

When a transaction is being rejected as invalid, querying on transaction status should show rejected reason.

Invalid transaction status could be queried by rest api for several minutes after it is rejected and client needs to know the rejected reason in order to decide on next action (re-submit same transaction payload perhaps or maybe transaction or transaction payload weren't formatted correctly).

Checking the TP/validator logs is not an appropriate solution for product, it is very hard to be done automatically and client that submits transactions might not have access to logs.

If transaction is rejected by TP, the exception message from TP can be displayed as rejected reason.

column1: New node cannot catch up the exsiting network without the older versions of custom TPs.
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
We recently upgraded our custom TP but forgot to archive the older version of TP. When we tried to add a new node to the existing network, we found that it would never catch up the network because it cannot validate the older version transactiosns..

So, how to solve this issue if we are not able to find the older version of TP?

Are there any best practices for TP version management?

I considered to use one handler for each version, but it is not very good for code reuse.

column1: Docs: Grafana documentation gives opentsdb_url port as 3000 instead of 8086
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
In the SysAdmin Guide for Grafana,

[https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sysadmin_guide/grafana_configuration.html#configure-the-sawtooth-validator-for-grafana]

Under "Configure the Sawtooth Validator for Grafana" step 2, there is:

opentsdb_url = "http://\{host}:3000"

AND under "Configure the Sawtooth REST API for Grafana" step 2, there is:

opentsdb_url = "http://\{host}:3000"

The port number is wrong. The port should be 8086, not 3000. Port 8086 is the InfluxDB port.

This error was introduced with the initial Grafana documentation sometime in 1.0.x. See STL-1130

 

Here is the Rocketchat session:
 * danintel 1:47 PM
 I get this error running grafana: `{{WARNING influx] Cannot write to 127.0.0.1: Service Unavailable}}`
 I follow the docs and the host stats display, but not Sawtooth stats (because of the above error from sawtooth-validator).
 * jsmitchell Owner 1:52 PM
 what argument are you giving to opentsdb for the validator?

 * danintel 2:01 PM  
  
 I added this to `{{validator.toml}}`:

opentsdb_url = "http://127.0.0.1:3000"
opentsdb_db = "metrics"
opentsdb_username = "lrdata"
opentsdb_password = "pwlrdata"

And this is in `{{telegraf.conf}}`:

[[outputs.influxdb]] 
  urls = ["http://localhost:8086"]
  database = "metrics" 
  username = "lrdata" 
  password = "pwlrdata"
 * jsmitchell Owner 2:02 PM
 port 3000 is wrong then

 * both the validator and telegraf deliver their metrics to an influxdb instance which grafana reads from

 * 
 change opentsdb_url to [http://localhost:8086|http://localhost:8086/]
 * danintel 2:05 PM
 I'll try that. The docs say: 
 "

 # The host and port for Open TSDB database used for metrics
 opentsdb_url = "http://\{host}:3000"
 "
 [See https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sysadmin_guide/grafana_configuration.html#configure-the-sawtooth-validator-for-grafana|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sysadmin_guide/grafana_configuration.html#configure-the-sawtooth-validator-for-grafana]

So to summarize, port 3000 is only for the Grafana GUI. It is not also used for shuttling metrics data.
 * jsmitchell Owner 2:05 PM
 @achenette ^ ⚠

 * rberg2 2:40 PM
 doh! it looks like I put the wrong port in there for the validator and rest-api. telegraf is correct. Sorry for the confusion.

column1: reject transaction by TP causes loops of retry
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
happens with sawtooth 1.1.x, with sawtooth 1.0 this does not reproduce.

After transaction processor rejects a transaction the validator gets into a loop of keep forwarding this transaction to the transaction processor. loop will end once a new valid transaction arrives.

expected behavior: after transaction is rejected it is marked as rejected and shouldn't be processed again by transaction processor.

column1: sawtooth-validator must be restarted if a consensus engine is restarted
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The `sawtooth-validator` must be restarted if a consensus engine is restarted.

If I restart devmode-engine-rust, say:
`sudo -u sawtooth devmode-engine-rust -vv --connect tcp://localhost:5050 `
The `sawtooth-validator` never reconnects to the new devmode-engine-rust process.

The workaround is to restart `sawtooth-validator` after restarting `devmode-engine-rust`

Note that vice-versa works--I can restart the validator and I do not need to restart the consensus engine.

This occurs on Sawtooth 1.0. It probably also occurs on Sawtooth 1.1.

Filing this as a bug per a recommendation in the FAQ code review:

{{generator/source/faq/consensus.rst
How do I restart a consensus engine?
------------------------------------
First stop the validator, then restart the consensus engine.
If you leave the validator engine running, it will not connect to the restarted consensus engine.
  @vaporos
vaporos 2 hours ago  Member
This should be considered a bug. Maybe we could link to a JIRA here.}}
( see https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-website/pull/27 )
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: sawtooth-supply-chain does not support latest release, Sawtooth 1.1 Bionic
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The current version of sawtooth-supply-chain repo uses Ubuntu 18 (Bionic) and the nightly (bleeding edge) Sawtooth 1.2.

I prefer something more stable--Sawtooth 1.1 (latest release, "Bumper"), which is only supported on Ubuntu 16 (Xenial).

*Workaround*
Patch sawtooth-supply-chain, I follow these steps:

{{git clone https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-supply-chain
cd sawtooth-supply-chain
git diff 50c404c >bionic.patch
patch --dry-run -R -p1 <bionic.patch
patch           -R -p1 <bionic.patch
sudo docker-compose up}}

(From Rocketchat #sawtooth-supply-chain discussion of January 24 and 29, 2019.)

From a Sawtooth FAQ review, this was suggested as a bug:
> generator/source/faq/installation.rst
>     $ git diff 50c404c >bionic.patch
>     $ patch --dry-run -R -p1 <bionic.patch
>     $ patch           -R -p1 <bionic.patch
>     $ sudo docker-compose up
>   @vaporos vaporos 4 hours ago  Member
> We probably consider the necessity of this patch a bug?

https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-website/pull/27

column1: Installing sawtooth nightly (1.2) results in unmet dependencies error
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Following these directions with Sawtooth nightly (1.2):
https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/app_developers_guide/ubuntu.html
results in an error:

{{$ sudo pkg install sawtooth
[sudo] password for dano:
sudo apt install sawtooth
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
 sawtooth : Depends: python3-sawtooth-poet-cli but it is not installable
            Depends: python3-sawtooth-poet-common but it is not installable
            Depends: python3-sawtooth-poet-core but it is not installable
            Depends: python3-sawtooth-poet-families but it is not installable
            Depends: python3-sawtooth-poet-simulator but it is not installable
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
monroe ~ $ uname -a
Linux monroe 4.15.0-45-generic #48-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jan 29 16:28:13 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
monroe ~ $ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS
Release:        18.04
Codename:       bionic}}

The problem is basically PoET packages are listed as dependencies, but do not exist (yet) for Sawtooth 1.2 nightly.

*Workaround #1*
You can also install Sawtooth with Docker. See:
https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/latest/app_developers_guide/docker.html

*Workaround #2*
If you wish to install the nightly development packages on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic), then, for now, specify the individual packages you wish to install instead of parent package ``sawtooth``.  For example, ``sudo apt-get install python3-sawtooth-cli python3-sawtooth-integration python3-sawtooth-rest-api python3-sawtooth-sdk python3-sawtooth-settings python3-sawtooth-signing python3-sawtooth-validator sawtooth-devmode-engine-rust``

Filing this JIRA issue was recommended during a review of Sawtooth FAQ additions:
>  vaporos 4 hours ago  Member
>  This should also be tied to some bug, otherwise we won't know when to remove the > 
 workaround from the FAQ.

column1: Broken GO SDK links in Sawtooth core docs
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The GO SDK links are broken on the SDK Reference intro page ([https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sdks.html]) in the Sawtooth core documentation.
 * Transaction Processor: [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/go_sdk/processor.html#http://]
 * Signing: [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/go_sdk/signing.html#http://]

It's not clear if the auto doc generation is broken or if the docs ARE being created but are stored in a different location.

A fix should also investigate why the doc adds `#http:://` to some links, including this one, and determine if it can be omitted. Note that working SDK links (in the past) have included this string, so the failure does not appear to be caused by this string.

column1: Documentation contains broken links
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
{quote}From *Marc Vauclair:*

This is to mention that the link: [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/tree/master/sdk] to be found here on page [https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/sawtooth] is not right:

The SDKs are not located any more in the sawtooth-core project but rather each in a separate Git.

The same is true for the links to be found at bottom of page: [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/1.1.4/app_developers_guide/sdk_table.html]

For example, the Sawtooth Python SDK is to be found here: [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-python] and the Rust SDK is to be found here: [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-rust].

 
{quote}

{code:java}
# Python version
$ sudo -u sawtooth sawadm genesis config-genesis.batch
Processing config-genesis.batch...
Generating /var/lib/sawtooth/genesis.batch

# Rust version

 {code}

column1: sawtooth-shell docker file does not refer to the right build and is missing an apt-get install statement
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Install sawtooth-core according to the instructions in [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/BUILD.md]

Execute the following commands:

cd ~/sawtooth-dev
git clone https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core.git
cd sawtooth-core
docker-compose -f docker/compose/sawtooth-build.yaml build
docker-compose build

Execute the command:

docker-compose up

It gives the following error in the trace:

sawtooth-shell-local | Traceback (most recent call last):
sawtooth-shell-local | File "/project/sawtooth-core/bin/sawtooth", line 30, in <module>
sawtooth-shell-local | from sawtooth_cli.main import main_wrapper
sawtooth-shell-local | File "/project/sawtooth-core/cli/sawtooth_cli/main.py", line 29, in <module>
sawtooth-shell-local | from sawtooth_cli.keygen import add_keygen_parser
sawtooth-shell-local | File "/project/sawtooth-core/cli/sawtooth_cli/keygen.py", line 22, in <module>
sawtooth-shell-local | from sawtooth_signing import create_context
sawtooth-shell-local | ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'sawtooth_signing'
sawtooth-shell-local exited with code 1

I have trace back the issue to the absence of the installation of python3-sawtooth-sdk in the docker/sawtooth-shell docker file.

I fixed it temporarily by replacing in docker/sawtooth-shell:

RUN echo "deb http://repo.sawtooth.me/ubuntu/ci bionic universe" >> /etc/apt/sources.list \
 && (apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv-keys 8AA7AF1F1091A5FD \
 || apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://p80.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-keys 8AA7AF1F1091A5FD) \
 && apt-get update

by (as found in the validator/DockerFile):

RUN echo "deb http://repo.sawtooth.me/ubuntu/nightly bionic universe" >> /etc/apt/sources.list \
 && (apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv-keys 44FC67F19B2466EA \
 || apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://p80.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-keys 44FC67F19B2466EA) \
 && apt-get update

and by adding:

RUN apt-get install -y -q \
 python3-sawtooth-sdk

While investigating the issue I also found that: 

validator/DockerFile, rest_api/Dockerfile, cli/Dockerfile depend on the 44FC key

while docker/sawtooth-shell, docker/sawtooth-av depend on the 8AA7 key

column1: All hexified strings must be lower case
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The documentation should state at all relevant places that hexified strings (e.g hexified hashes, hexified signatures) used in the transactions and in the batches must be lower case (i.e. using 0-9, a-f and not 0-9, A-F).

You stumble on this issue if you program clients not using the Sawtooth provided SDKs and you use your own hexifier (this means that one potential place to add this information is in: docs/source/app_developers_guide/no_sdk.rst).

 

Failing that, some commands will succeed and others not.

For example, I succeeded in getting transactions accepted with upper cased hex, in having them visible in the sawtooth transaction list command but not able to execute the sawtooth transaction show on the resulting transaction ID because show cannot work with transaction IDs containing upper case letters A-F.

This change is valid for all versions of the documentation.

column1: Make consensus engine configuration backwards compatible
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently, consensus engine configuration (using on-chain settings) in master breaks backwards compatibility; an existing network could not be updated since it would not contain the required settings.

This problem will need to be solved to ensure backwards compatibility with other 1.x versions

column138:
30/Mar/19 7:22 AM;danintel;Here's a further datapoint. I got this working on Internet (not behind a proxy) by using:
* Seth changeset 52a051 from 2018 (prior to ST 1.1 & Bionic changes)
* Sawtooth 1.0 Docker images

Then I changed Docker containers from ST 1.0 to 1.1 images (specifically 1.1.4) and it did not work.
That is the validator panics as above.  So the validator regression or incompatibility was introduced prior to the Sawtooth 1.1.4 release.
;;;

column1: Sawtooth Validator Reconnection Issue
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Reporting on behalf of someone else:

When I restart the validator node, after 4-5 such re-starts it stops writing to its ledger as well as stops broadcasting transactions to the other validators in the network. I have therefore created a set up on Minikube that you might be able to run, in case it would help in locating the root cause.

This is what I have done:
 # Taken Sawtooth’s sample file (i.e. sawtooth-kubernetes-default-poet.yaml) and retrofitted my changes for persisting the blockfiles and associated files required for validator resilience. I have made persistent the directories that were recommended by intel
 # Created a separate file for creating Kubernetes persistent volume claims in sawtooth-kubernetes-default-volume.yaml so that I can use the same with either my custom script or with the default sawtooth script

This will enable you to test the pod restart scenario with the Sawtooth provided transaction processors and try recreating the problem. 

The steps to be followed are:
 # Install Minikube
 # Run the command kubectl apply -f sawtooth-kubernetes-default-volume.yaml to create the volume claims
 # Then run kubectl get pv and kubectl get pvc to confirm that the persistent volume and it’ claims are created correctly
 # Run kubectl apply -f sawtooth-kubernetes-default-poet.yaml
 # Check if pods starting with name sawtooth-0, sawtooth-3 and sawtooth-4 are running
 # Check for the services ports using command kubectl get services
 # Create a record using intkey tp by connecting to the url of the pod/service whose name starts with sawtooth-0..
 # Check whether the record is present on all 3 nodes by using intkey list turn by turn with each service
 # Delete the pod whose name starts with sawtooth-0.. Using the command kubectl delete po sawtooth-0…..
 # Run kubectl get pods till you see the pod starting with sawtooth-0 having restarted
 # Repeat steps 7 to 10 a few times and the problem will surface post 4-5 attempts

Anyone have a solid deployment script?  Or story?;;;

column1: A doc page-not-found error jumps out of docs into Sawtooth website
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
If a doc file or link isn't found, the user sees a 404 page for the Sawtooth website, not the documentation. The only offered link is to the Sawtooth home page (plus the standard website nav at the top). This takes the user out of the docs and into the website.

Instead, the user should see a doc-specific "page not found" message that includes links to the top-level doc contents, a doc search, and "return to previous page" link, if possible.
column39:
To see an example of the problem, go to the Sawtooth SDK API Reference landing page:
[https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sdks.html]

Then click on one of the Go SDK links: 
[Transaction Processor|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/go_sdk/processor.html#http://]

[Signing|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/go_sdk/signing.html#http://]

column1: Send raw transaction header to transaction processor
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
RFC text/0000-raw-txn-header.md describes in brief the need to have serialized transaction header sent to transaction processor.
 # Introduce required proto changes, set EXPANDED as default.
 # Introduce a way for application developer to choose header style before registering transactiion processor with validator.
 # Either raw header bytes or de-serialized transaction header is sent in TpProcessRequest, not both.
 # Validator to clue SDK engine about its version by sending back request_header_style in TpRegisterResponse.
 # MAX_SDK_PROTOCOL_VERSION is the maximum version that the validator can support. The SDK shall consider registration attempt unsuccessful if validator cannot support a feature.

Please refer to [hyperledger/sawtooth-rfcs#23 |https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-rfcs/pull/23]for detailed description.

column1: Blocks stop publishing after a day
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
After a little over 24 hours, my network stops processing blocks.

I have a network of two servers. Each runs a docker-compose config containing validator, poet, etc.

I am using these images (two are our own, including a Transaction Processor):
{code:none}
  settings-tp:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-settings-tp:1.1.5
  identity-tp:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-identity-tp:1.1.5
  influxdb:
    image: influxdb:1.5
  grafana:
    image: grafana/grafana:6.1.0
  projectname-endpoint:
    image: projectdomain/sawtooth-projectname-endpoint:1.0.0-alpha1
  projectname-tp:
    image: projectdomain/sawtooth-projectname-tp:1.0.0-alpha1
  validator:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-validator:1.1.5
  rest-api:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-rest-api:1.1.5
  shell:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-all:1.1
  poet-engine:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-poet-engine:1.1
  poet-validator-registry-tp:
    image: hyperledger/sawtooth-poet-validator-registry-tp:1.1
{code}
I am running a script that is generating transactions and batches to update random user entries.

Our set up contains one "main" node, which is allowed to write and one "client" node that is only allowed to read.

The log below is from the main node, each `Command: user -  update -  B=29` is logged at the top of our Transaction Processor handle function. At the very bottom you can see the POST logs. Those are when my script calls to create new batches to update the users. However, as you can see, those updates aren't being sent to the transaction processor (because it would result in a "Command" in the log.

column1: poet-sgx use the version 2 of remote attestation protocol which is not supported anymore by Intel
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: In the poet-sgx consensus, during the remote attestation protocol, the requests for get_signature_revocation_lists and post_verify_attestation are made for the v2 of the attestation protocol, which is not supported anymore. A simple fix is to change the path by v3 in order to use the correct version.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135:
04/Aug/19 1:07 AM;arsulegai;This is addressed in PoET and the code is merged to the sawtooth-poet repository. PoET 2 will have V3 SGX API already when the repository is created.

This issue can be closed.;;;

column1: Patch Validator and REST API to work with IPv6

2) Patch REST API to accept an IPv6 address in bracket format (e.g. [::]).

GitHub pull request: https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/2093

column1: settings list return "Error parsing message"
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
*How to reproduce:*
 # Start services: validator, settings, cli, rest-api

$ sawtooth settings list
{code}

 

*Actual behavior:*

I get an error:

Traceback (most recent call last):

column1: Not able to sign message from seth-rpc
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
I want to submit a contract creation transaction from terminal via seth-rpc. I created myalias as an account in seth-cli-go and then i connected to seth-rpc and try to unlock the account but got error, "Account not found".

I added  "- sawtooth:/root/.sawtooth" under the "volumes" section of seth-cli-go and then it worked.

After that i ran `curl -d '\{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "eth_sign", "id": 1, "params": [myaliasAddress, message]}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" localhost:3030` to get signature of myalias on  `message` but i got error "Account with address `myaliasAddress` not found."

I am stuck on this for the last 2 days and have already spent 12hrs on this, can't find any solution anywhere!!
column39: Ubuntu 18.04 bionic
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

06/May/19 7:05 PM;nanspro;One more thing, when trying to unlock account or connect seth-rpc like `

seth-rpc --connect tcp://validator:4004 --bind 0.0.0.0:3030` the command never returns back to bash(it's always stuck as shown in the image);;;

column1: Genesis Block Invalid Predecessor (GBIP) and PENDING Transactions
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column39:
I have experienced this bug in the following environments (all single-node environments with all components running locally and transactions submmited from the same machine):

Ubuntu 16.0.4 VM running sawtooth 1.1.4 and devmode consensus

Ubuntu 16.0.4 VM running sawtooth 1.1.5 and devmode consensus

Amazon AWS image running sawtooth 1.1.4 and devmode consensus


I have tested with a variety of TPs running, but in general the bug is reproducable just running settings and intkey.

In addition, the first time I experienced this bug was about a month and a half ago using multiple Ubunutu 16.0.4 nodes running PoET consensus, but I was new to hyperledger and thus I did not do testing or record any information.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135: 24/May/19 2:30 AM;Atlowell;UPDATE: This issue seems to be caused by STL-1573;;;
column136: 07/Jun/19 1:06 AM;Atlowell;UPDATE: Can also be caused by failing to specify a validator key as in STL-1610;;;
column137: 15/Jun/19 4:11 AM;Atlowell;UPDATE: I continue to have this bug at random intervals.  Even when the two bugs I have identified that can cause this are addressed, the consensus engine can still fail the consensus check for the genesis block.;;;
column138:
19/Oct/19 1:15 AM;Atlowell;Update: I was experiencing this issue when running a docker container from the sawtooth-default.yaml file from 1.1.5.  Editing the file from "image: hyperledger/sawtooth-devmode-engine-rust:1.1" to image: "hyperledger/sawtooth-devmode-engine-rust:chime" made the bug go away.  The devmode docker container using chime showed version 1.2.2.

From my understanding, the genesis block's validation is the responsibility of the validator, and it seems like it is being validated.  However, the devmode consensus engine in 1.1.5 is failing validation on the genesis block, which is causing the validator to reject the next block published due to an invalid predecessor.  This issue seems to be addressed in PR #11 on the sawtooth devmode repo, HOWEVER, that PR wasn't added until version 1.2.3.  It hasn't been backported to 1.2.2 either, since the logging changes in that PR do not reflect on the 1.2.2 version that is working in testing.

From my inspection via diff tools, the only differences in devmode engine source files between 1.1.5 and 1.2.2 are newline formatting.  As a result, it seems that the most likely cause of the difference between behavior in 1.1.5 and 1.2.2 has to do with the environment and setup files or the libraries used.   For example, the rust sdk versions used are different, and there are several commits between the forking of the repo and version 1.2.2 involving changes to JENKINSFILE, ci, docker-compose, lint, etc...

EDIT: Right after posting this (after testing many times), I started experiencing the same issue, even with 1.2.2.  This is not very surprising, as in my months-long struggle with this issue, it tends to be very intermittent.  My hope is that PR #11 addresses it once and for all.  I will test extensively with 1.2.3 when it is released on chime.;;;

column1: Fix egregious terminology inconsistencies in Sawtooth docs

Update key terminology that has shifted since the epoch:
 * Sawtooth node (not "validator", because that's a component, not the whole node)
 * -PoET CFT (vs PoET simulator)-
 * PoET Validator Registry (not Validator Registry).
 * Devmode (not Dev mode, dev mode, or devmode).

column1: Describe consensus defaults
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Describe the "default fallback" for consensus engines.
----
(PREVIOUS CONTENT)
 Note in the Sawtooth core documentation that these on-chain consensus settings are required (no longer ignored) after release 1.1:
 * {{sawtooth.consensus.algorithm.name}}
 * {{sawtooth.consensus.algorithm.version}}

The previous setting, sawtooth.consensus.algorithm, is fully deprecated and should not be used.

This information could be part of a topic or procedure on upgrading from 1.1 and earlier releases, when available.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Provide better support for consensus backwards compatibility
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
From private discussions:
 # update registration to allow a list of (name, version) the engine can handle
 # update PoET to handle (poet, 0.1) and (PoET, 0.1)
 # for backwards compatibility just map {{sawtooth.consensus.algorithm=engine}} to {{sawtooth.consensus.algorithm.name=engine}} and {{sawtooth.consensus.algorithm.version=0.1}}

column1: Add consensus engine info to Sysadmin + App Dev Guides
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Provide admin-specific information about the consensus interface for the System Administrator's Guide, with links to the dynamic consensus overview in the Introduction (and other consensus-related information as appropriate).  This info should summarize how to choose and configure a consensus engine.

For the App Dev Guide, add links to this information.

------------------------

PREVIOUS CONTENT

Provide appdev-specific information about the consensus interface for the Application Developer's Guide, with links to the consensus interface topic in the Architecture Guide.  For the App Dev Guide, this info should summarize how to choose and configure a consensus engine.

------------------------

ORIGINAL CONTENT

Describe new consensus interface (API, consensus engines-, SDKs-) based on the RFC, presentations, and other info sources.

This information is needed for the PBFT documentation: must briefly define/explain the Sawtooth consensus interface in once place, so that the consensus engine steps in the procedures can link to this information.

Consider using the current "Dynamic Consensus Algorithm" section in the Sawtooth introduction, and replacing the intro's section with a shorter summary.

Also document consensus fallback mechanism for existing chains on networks upgraded from 1.0. Implementing PR: [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/2056]

column1: Transaction Purging RFC
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Write an RFC to propose one or more solutions to the problem of purging invalid transactions (where non-publishing nodes do not remove invalid transactions from their pending queues).

This is an issue that occurs on networks using leader-based consensus algorithms.

column1: Add logging backend for Sabre smart contracts
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently, there is no way to retrieve logs from a smart contract run in Sabre. With the move to running all smart contracts in Grid to Sabre, we need to provide a way to send logs out of the WASM VM. 

This will require investigating how to write a logging backend and how it will work with WASM. The goal at the minimum is this story is to return why a transaction was invalid.

 

This will cause patch release to Sabre TP and Sabre SDK
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135: 04/Jun/19 11:10 PM;agunde;comment from old story "Implement a logging backed for the Sabre Rust SDK. This logging backend will martial the logging messages outside the WASM container and carefully log them. (It is important that these log messages be handled as untrusted strings.)";;;

column1: Add no-op logging macros in sabre-sdk
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
We could supply some no-op macros if not wasm, so as not to repeat [cfg(not(target_arch = "wasm32"))] statement before every log message. This will also simplify updating smart contracts in the future once we have a logging backend for sabre smart contracts because we will not need to remove the cfg statements.

This will cause a bump to the major version of Sabre TP and Sabre SDK

After turn it with web3 from ASCII to hex string and send it through rest-api as batch, the result is that disk usage is increasing exponentially in every new transaction. For example it may take up to 1GB of disk storage for each transaction

*Second point is that:* the transaction processor with that kind of smart contracts with that kind of big bytes messages takes really long time for the transaction processor and the validator to commit the block, *up to minutes*, and if you send a second transaction before the block validation of the first transaction finished then the second block takes only the batch of the blockinfo and not the seth transaction.

column1: Devmode Consensus Engine Configuration Issue
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The devmode consensus engine configuration file has the command line arguments commented out, which is inconsistent with other components of the system.

In addition, there is a statement in main.rs which is intended to set a default connection value of "tcp://localhost:5050", however, if the engine is run with the command line arguments commented out, or with command line arguments that do not specify a server connection, the consensus engine does not connect and cannot validate.

Seems to be a cause of STL 1535
column39: The issue exists in both Sawtooth versions 1.2 and 1.1 using the latest devmode consensus engine available from the apt-get repositories.  dpkg shows the devmode consensus engine version to be 1.1.5 in both of these scenarios.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135: 18/Oct/19 3:45 AM;Atlowell;UPDATE: Second part of this issue seems to relate to sawtooth core PR #1966 being applied to master branch right before devmode was moved to a new repo, thus it was never applied to branch 1-1.;;;;
column136: 24/Feb/20 2:00 PM;arsulegai;This has been ported to 1.1 branch as well. PR [#2262|https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/2262] solves the issue on 1.1 branch.;;;
column137: 24/Feb/20 2:05 PM;arsulegai;[~Atlowell] I didn't get your first part in this issue. Are you asking to uncomment the args passed by default?;;;
column138: 25/Feb/20 4:39 AM;Atlowell;[~arsulegai] At least as of the time I reported this issue, the configuration files of all other sawtooth components had the default args uncommented.  The sawtooth devmode engine had its commented, which led to inconsistent and confusing behavior;;;

column1: Replace all instances of agunde406/rust-crypto with rust-crypto-wasm

column38: When Sabre was first written there was not a version of rust-crypto that could be compiled into wasm so I created a fork that removed everything except the functiality we needed for the smart contracts so it could be compiled into wasm. Now there is a fork of rust crypto that can be compiled in called rust-crypto-wasm. All instance of agunde406/rust-crypto and should be replace with rust-crypto-wasm = "0.3"

column1: Update documentation on how to make smaller WASM files
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Research the changes needed to automatically reduce the size of a compiled WASM file.

The Sabre doc "Compiling the Contract" recommends using a script to reduce the size of a compiled WASM file: [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/sabre/nightly/master/application_developer_guide.html#compiling-the-contract]

The doc has a link to a web page that which references the wasm-gc script: [https://www.hellorust.com/news/native-wasm-target.html]

However, the wasm-gc repo has information about recent changes that make the script unnecessary: [https://github.com/alexcrichton/wasm-gc] .

The best way to reduce the size of the wasm binaries should be researched and added to the documentation

column1: Contexts leaked on Unscheduled, Inflight Transactions
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Contexts are leaked when a transaction has been sent for execution by the executor, but unscheduled while in flight.  When the executor sets the result on the scheduler, it silently returns, and nothing is done with the outstanding context.

column1: Change Default Key of sawset CLI, or make "--key" Mandatory
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
If no "–key" argument is specified for the "sawset genesis" CLI command (and other sawset commands as well), the userkey is used.  While this is good practice for other CLI commands, users may want sawset to use the validator keypair instead.  The system administrator and developer guides recommend different strategies.  This can lead to confusing behavior for a user.

In testing, failing to specifiy a validator key (thus causing the user key to be the default) has led to issues, and this may be a cause of STL-1535.  Further testing will be needed to prove this link.

Proposed solution is to either change the default signer key for sawset genesis (and perhaps other commands) to the validator key, or make the "key" CLI argument mandatory.

column1: Compilation error 'Unable to detect OpenSSL version'
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When running the build of Seth vs master, which has no new changes since the last successful build - we receive the following rust compilation error

 

 
{noformat}
error: failed to run custom build command for `openssl v0.9.24`
process didn't exit successfully: `/project/sawtooth-seth/cli/target/debug/build/openssl-7d464e70a21ffa53/build-script-build` (exit code: 101)
--- stderr
thread 'main' panicked at 'Unable to detect OpenSSL version', /root/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/openssl-0.9.24/build.rs:16:14
note: Run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace.

warning: build failed, waiting for other jobs to finish...
error: build failed
Service 'seth-cli' failed to build: The command '/bin/sh -c cargo build && cp ./target/debug/seth /project/sawtooth-seth/bin/seth' returned a non-zero code: 101{noformat}
The base image is pulling in  openssl-amd64-1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.1 which is incompatible with cargo's openssl v0.9.24.  

For what it's worth it looks to me as if that is getting selected because of reqwest 0.8.8 which is subject to this issue (see [https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/336)] 

Since nothing has changed in the source, I can only presume this break sources either from the openssl getting updated in the base version, or from upstream in the sawtooth-rust-sdk or other.

column135:
19/Jun/19 12:00 AM;pschwarz;This has been fixed as of: https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-seth/pull/106

column1: AWS Marketplace image can't process transactions
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
A default, out of the box AWS marketplace based sawtooth instance (v1.1.4) is unable to process transactions.  I have repeated this process on 3 separate nodes, with the same results. 

It is possible to fix this by opening up the sawtooth ports to the local subnet and rebooting the box.
 * NO configuration has been created or modified (in /etc/sawtooth)
 * Using ami-092d2d11e82fbf971 in ap-northeast-2
 * launch new instance, allowing only ssh

{code:java}
ssh ubuntu@public-ip
sawtooth transaction list # shows 1 transaction
sudo -H -u sawtooth intket set mykey 100
sawtooth transaction list # shows 1 transaction
curl http://127.0.0.1:8008/batch_statuses?id=...
 > "pending"
{code}
After opening 4004/5050/8800/8008 and rebooting, *transactions are processed*.  However, the transactions submitted previously are gone (they were always in pending, I'm guessing that is why)

!image-2019-06-17-11-07-25-793.png!

 In related news, after rebooting I have errors like this in the logs which make it feel like the unit files don't depend on each other properly and shutdown out of order.  
{code}
# cat rest_api-error.log
[02:49:46.385 [MainThread] base_events ERROR] Task was destroyed but it is pending!
task: <Task pending coro=<StateDeltaSubscriberHandler._handle_disconnect() running at /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_rest_api/state_delta_subscription_handler.py:175>>

# cast validator-error.log
[02:54:31.835 [MainThread] (unknown file) ERROR] error executing main
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_validator/server/cli.py", line 290, in main
    validator.stop()
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_validator/server/core.py", line 489, in stop
    if not t.is_alive():
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 1113, in is_alive
    self._wait_for_tstate_lock(False)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 1069, in _wait_for_tstate_lock
    assert self._is_stopped
AssertionError
{code}
h2. Upgrading to v1.1.5

Attempting to upgrade the base 1.1.4 image to 1.1.5 goes smoothly from the package side.  However, I haven't found any way to get any transactions to process on it. 

There are no errors in the validator/rest-api logs (except for the same error it shows on reboot).

!image-2019-06-17-11-28-47-204.png!
column39:
AWS
Marketplace 1.1.4 AMI

Additionally, we should be able to set and get at addresses with multiple address components.

Note that the glossary must continue to include an entry for PoET simulator/PoET-sim, because it's used in blog posts, announcements, on chat.hyperledger.org, and elsewhere.

Also consider whether PoET-SGX should be renamed or "also called" PoET BFT.  In any case, the docs need a better description of the CFT/BFT differences in PoET 1.0.

column1: Default poet docker compose file validator registration issue
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The docker-compose file - *sawtooth-default-poet.yaml* in the repository is not able to bring up a network always. Few validators are left out(unregistered) at times. Subsequent transaction submission leads to invalid blocks in validity check at the PoET engine -

_sawtooth-poet-engine-2 | [2019-06-14 07:39:47.381 ERROR poet_block_verifier] Block 1fdb1401 rejected: Received block from an unregistered validator 03caa53f...42cd80d0_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-4 | [2019-06-14 07:39:47.535 ERROR poet_block_verifier] Block 1fdb1401 rejected: Received block from an unregistered validator 03caa53f...42cd80d0_
column39:
OS - Ubuntu 16.04

Docker version - 18.03.1-ce

Docker-compose version - 1.21.2, build a133471
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column135:
25/Jun/19 3:10 PM;raghav.aneja14;Unlike Sawtooth 1.1 , this error message is logged in Sawtooth 1.2 .

The root cause is the stale volume data/keys that gets created dynamically by the docker-engine on start, which doesn't clear on normal shutting of the network.

Hence, the docker volumes needs to be either cleared or destroyed on shutting the docker network using command " docker-compose down -v" .

 ;;;
column136: 25/Jun/19 11:58 PM;dan.middleton@intel.com;Is there a PR associated with this defect?;;;
column137: 26/Jun/19 4:09 PM;raghav.aneja14;[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-website/pull/53]  is the PR , which addresses the issue.;;;

column1: Future timeout error on summarize block
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
PoET engine throws Future Timeout Error on summarize_block() call in engine. Occurs only when rate of transaction submission is relatively high(~30tps). Transactions being submitted using intkey-workload & smallbank-workload tools.

When run using dockers, the poet engine throws below timeout exception -

_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | [2019-06-11 03:16:31.780 ERROR engine] Unhandled exception in message loop_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | Traceback (most recent call last):_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_poet_engine/engine.py", line 189, in start_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | self._try_to_publish()_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_poet_engine/engine.py", line 203, in _try_to_publish_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | block_id = self._finalize_block()_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_poet_engine/engine.py", line 115, in _finalize_block_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | summary = self._summarize_block()_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_poet_engine/engine.py", line 107, in _summarize_block_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | return self._service.summarize_block()_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_sdk/consensus/zmq_service.py", line 108, in summarize_block_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | response_type=response_type)_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_sdk/consensus/zmq_service.py", line 32, in _send_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | ).result(self._timeout).content_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_sdk/messaging/future.py", line 63, in result_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | message_type))_
_sawtooth-poet-engine-0 | sawtooth_sdk.messaging.future.FutureTimeoutError: Future timed out waiting for response to CONSENSUS_SUMMARIZE_BLOCK_REQUEST_

The validator does not show any error in the logs. But the node would fall out of the network and start throwing backpressure as the block generation flow stalls & client requests pile up.

This issue has been reported from several enthusiasts in the community as well.

column135:
03/Jul/19 11:39 PM;arsulegai;[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-poet/pull/38]

Is raised to solve the issue described here.;;;
column136:
03/Jul/19 11:40 PM;arsulegai;Issue happened because of missing condition check in poet_fork_resolver.py when same block arrives for compare_chains()

Detailed analysis:
 * The _pending_forks_to_resolve is to store chain heads of all the forks.
 * Crash occurred because the PendingForks data structure had element in queue, which is not in dictionary. This can only happen if duplicate entries are added to this data structure.
 * Validator can send duplicate blocks, which consensus engine has to take care of.
 * Long before the crash, there’s a block which is sent for fork resolution and consensus engine asks validator to commit the block which is already committed.
 * This corrupted environment in engine.py which corrupts PendingForks;;;

column1: Inconsistent data type for block numbers
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38: Apparently owing to a hangover from Tendermint integration, parts of the Seth and Burrow codebases use a signed int64 type for block numbers, and other parts use the (correct, IMV) unsigned type.  Apart from being a bit unsightly this causes issues with interfaces, will ultimately break the network (in about 30 years), and makes the code generally fragile to maintain.

column1: Seth builds again private fork of Burrow, not Hyperledger version
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Seth currently builds against Kenneth Koski's private fork of Burrow for its EVM, not the Hyperledger mainline.

Whilst done for fine reasons in the past this is a serious hygiene issue.  Especially with security reviews and other quality processes only looking at the main Hyperledger code bases we need to make sure everything is consistent and under the control of the community.

column1: Rest API crashes when no content-type header is found
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
When posting to the /batches/ endpoint, the API crashes and returns a 500.  It will continue to service requests.

The right response for an unknown/unaccepted content type is 415.  In the case of the /batches/ endpoint, where there is no allowed content type other than application/octet-stream (as far as I know), the content type could be inferred/assumed if missing, or a nice error thrown saying what the user should do ("Please add the header ...")

 

 
{code:java}
saw.api | [2019-07-05 07:08:18.062 ERROR web_protocol] Error handling request
saw.api | Traceback (most recent call last):
saw.api | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/aiohttp/web_protocol.py", line 416, in start
saw.api | resp = yield from self._request_handler(request)
saw.api | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/aiohttp/web.py", line 323, in _handle
saw.api | resp = yield from handler(request)
saw.api | File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_rest_api/route_handlers.py", line 139, in submit_batches
saw.api | if request.headers['Content-Type'] != 'application/octet-stream':
saw.api | File "multidict/_multidict.pyx", line 124, in multidict._multidict._Base.__getitem__ (multidict/_multidict.c:3486)
saw.api | File "multidict/_multidict.pyx", line 119, in multidict._multidict._Base._getone (multidict/_multidict.c:3421)
saw.api | KeyError: "Key not found: 'Content-Type'"
{code}

column1: Support offchain configuration for the pbft members.
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Please support offchain configuration for the pbft members.

It’s very dangerous to update the onchain settings for pbft members. The network admin may update the pbft members list in an incorrect way like the number is less than 4 or the public key is not surrouned by quotes, these wrong configurations will make the pbft engine crash and the network will never have a chance to go back.

Another solution is to write our own client to update the onchain settings with validity checking. This needs every network admin to write his own tools.. An official client should be provided.
column85: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Reorder block validation in validator
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Update the validator:
 * Send a block to consensus as soon as it's received/created
 * Wait for a check_block() request from consensus
 * Validate the block and send a BlockValid/BlockInvalid

This was the original intent of the consensus API behavior, but right now the validator validates the block first before sending it to consensus.

This will require updates to PBFT (and possibly devmode, raft)

column1: Enable Heartbeats over all ZMQ connections
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Currently, only the validator to validator connections send heartbeats to keep the connection alive. This should be expanded to include all zmq connections (to TPs, REST API, State Delta exports etc..) to keep these connections alive. 

This can be done by removing the option to turn heartbeats on in interconnect and just alwasy sending the ping messages. This requires validating that the rest api's, tp, and state delta exports simply ignore these messages.

Doc source file (in master branch): 
[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/docs/source/app_developers_guide/about_events.rst]

----------

Question on #sawtooth channel in chat.hyperledger.org ([https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/sawtooth?msg=ZqQQRBKCpuET2sqcy] ):
"what exactly is the content of this event field..is there a schema for this event_data which can be used for deserialization. could not find in the doc"

Answer from arsulegai ( [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/sawtooth?msg=pywiRv78gfv5GDJLv] ):
Here's the proto structure to deserialize the state-delta event [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/b57b44dfc0e8725aefa17f4d3af131b9f99aa969/protos/transaction_receipt.proto#L51]

column1: Docs: Fix batch completeness info in Arch Guide - Journal - The Completer
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
In the Sawtooth Architecture Guide, "The Completer" section in the Journal topic has incorrect text in the bullet item that describes batch completeness.  To fix it, remove the second sentence in this bullet item:
 * A batch is considered complete when all of its dependent transactions exist in the current chain or have been delivered to the BlockPublisher. -Once a batch is formally complete, it is delivered to the ChainController.-

Doc source (in master branch): 
[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/docs/source/architecture/journal.rst]

 

----------

Question in #sawtooth on chat.hyperledger.org: [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/sawtooth?msg=g9J2wcKGfTj8cgeEr]

column1: javascript sdk monorepo
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
It would be useful to split the sdk into different packages to let developer chose wich package to install and use.
This will solve also the problem of importing part of the sdk into a web application:
processor and messaging packages are not useful in a web app.

the idea is to use lerna to separate the sdk into:
 * sawtooth-sdk-messaging
 * sawtooth-sdk-signing
 * sawtooth-sdk-processor
 * sawtooth-sdk-protobuf

column1: Memory runs out on block catchup if backlog is too high
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
This issue has caused several developers to post on the #sawtooth-core-dev list.  When a new or previously disabled validator is added back into the blockchain, it must catch up on blocks previously validated, but not on its chain.  If the number of blocks or size of these blocks that must be added to the new validator are greater than the available RAM on the validator node, the node will crash.  If auto re-start is enabled, it will continuously restart and crash. We figured out this shows up in a NON Docker environment.  Docker will enable memory-swap and take the excess blocks and spool them to disk, if so enabled.  Thus this issue does not show up in a Docker environment.  Unless your environment has memory-swap enabled, the spooling of blocks to the new validator node will continue until such time available RAM is exhausted and the node is re-started. 

How we recreated this issue:
 # Configured a cluster of five nodes with PBFT in Docker Compose, Added a 1 GB memory limit to the validator.
 # Brought up the first four nodes, which is enough for consensus.
 # Ran intkey load for an hour, roughly 50 tps.
 # Activated the final (fifth) node, and observed the memory usage. Maxed out at 1 GB, and swapped over 2 GB to disk before I interrupted it (was progressing, but slow because of swapping the was handled automatically by Docker)
 # Disabled swap for Validator dockers and restarted. Validator now immediately crashes when it reaches 1 GB memory limit.
 # Restarted validator with much larger memory limit (4-8GB) and catchup completes successfully.

This issue is related to STL-972 which is asking for a limiter to be added to reduce the number of blocks released at a time to catchup blocks on a new validator node or one re-entering after being taken offline.

column1: Block syncing issue with the validators
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
I have a setup of 3 nodes which are rarely ever given batches to process. The batches themselves usually hold one transaction. After a period of time these nodes randomly stop syncing to each other. one node is at 244 blocks while others are at 302.

Other to nodes are able to accept transactions and publish blocks but this node doesn't seem to be responsive and doesn't throw anything in logs either. Restarting the node with all of its services or restarting the whole network doesn't make any difference. 

Eventually we gave up on the node and stopped it. And set up a new node with the same private key, configurations and services. This time it is able to sync all the blocks.

Attached are the yaml files and validator logs after restarting it. It seems that the validator has received the blocks but is keeping them as pending, while TP is up and setting up another node with same config and private key with same docker-compose file it seemed to have synced all the blocks. so the smart-contract seems to be deterministic still.

column1: Sawtooth - PBFT - Catchup Stalls
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
Validator version 1.1.5 (also replicated in 1.2.X)

PBFT version 1.0.1 (also replicated in 1.0.2)

During the catchup process, the node often stalls (gets stuck at a block that is not the current head). We were seeing this very frequently in our network of 5 nodes across AWS and Azure. About 60-70% of our runs resulted in this scenario. Once stalled the node stays in the stalled state until restarted (in which case again it may or it may not catchup). 

After several troubleshooting steps, we identified the root cause to the fact that the PBFT engine may receive (or process) blocks out of sequence in which case it discards the block. S

 

Attaching a specific run of the PBFT log in our case that demonstrates the above. More details as follows with detailed refernce to the line numbers in the attached pbft-stall.log, 

 

What is happening here is that we are trying to catchup a new node that has no prior blocks. Line 58 in the PBFT logs is confusing since it says internal error for the genesis block (since the block number is 0, but the seq num for PBFT is 1). But it already had previously got it in the start state in line 32, and processed it in line 39. In line 60 the PBFT engine gets block number 1 from the validator. It then gets block 2 in line 70 and marks block 1 valid in line 83/84 and commits in line 120. Meanwhile it has continued to receive blocks and put them in the log marked as unvalidated (pending processing I guess). At line 130 you can see it receives block 6, but it hasnt yet received block 4 or block 5 - so it throws an error and discards that block. In line 139 it gets block 4 and then line 149 block 5. Subsequently as block 7 on wards come in but are discarded since it doesnt have block 6/discarded it previously. Meanwhile it continues processing and commits upto block 4 (line 253). But on block 5 it doesnt have block 6 for the seal and makes a Seal Request (which will be ignored by the rest of the network) line 167. Subsequent to that it pretty much stalls in the catchup since it has no more blocks to process.... I am guessing if a new batch is sent and a new block request came in, then the validator would try to again find previous blocks but it has a lot of catching up to do and might stall again (we had a scenario a couple of months back when a node mysteriously caught up after a few days, but I think it looks like it might have incrementally caught up/ stalled each time a new block was processed )

[2020-05-15 01:44:06.927 ERROR interconnect] Received a message on address tcp://127.0.0.1:4004 that caused an error: too many values to unpack (expected 2)
Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_validator/networking/interconnect.py", line 368, in _receive_message
 yield from self._socket.recv_multipart()
ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)

 

The most important question is: Are you gonna still support C++ SDK? When I see your effort and contributions I got feelings that you pushing development into RUST and now necessary Python. 

 

You setup the priority as you want to. For me this issue is critical because not any home-made transaction processor can work without the fix. It of course forced me to fixed it already.

column1: Transactions are processed only in pairs
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
I've encountered situation when transactions are processed only in pairs, i.e. first transaction is not submitted until the second one is pushed to REST API. What could be an issue? Thanks in advance.
Update. This was caused by adding new validator to blockchain. We passed a list of existing peers to this validator on start, but all existing validators still did not  have new one in their peer list. Documentation stated that peering is bidirectional, but seems that it does not work this way.
After deleting this extra node everything started working.

column1: Go SDK should not require a protobuf package in the Go path
column11: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column38:
The Go SDK requires a protobuf package in the Go path, because the SDK itself uses imports like "protobuf/transaction_pb2". Before Go 1.13 this is already completely against the principles of idiomatic Go and how package paths should look like, but at least it worked. 

After Go 1.13, when modules became the new standard, this approach no longer works. This "hacky" protobuf package will NEVER get vendored when using `go mod vendor` and it will cause errors like this:

```
# github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/processor
vendor/github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/processor/context.go:330:3: cannot use event (type *"github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/protobuf/events_pb2".Event) as type *"protobuf/events_pb2".Event in field value
vendor/github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/processor/worker.go:57:30: cannot use header (type *"protobuf/transaction_pb2".TransactionHeader) as type *"github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/protobuf/transaction_pb2".TransactionHeader in argument to findHandler
```
and

```
/core/vendor/github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-sdk-go/protobuf/batch_pb2/batch.pb.go:10:2: cannot find package "." in:
 /core/vendor/protobuf/transaction_pb2
```

 OS version: x86_64 GNU/Linux
 Sawtooth version: 1.2
 Environment details (virtual, physical, etc.): physical and docker
 Steps to reproduce the issue:
1. Install Sawtooth as according the docs
2. Use `go mod vendor` to prepare the vendor directory
3. Create a docker image

 Actual results: See above
 Expected results: Successful image creation
